characters: "CHRISTMAS 1972." HUNDREDS OF B-52 STRIKES, BOMBS POURIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven men in shirts and ties are seated around a table in darkened room.  They are smoking Cuban cigars, idly watching the film. TITLE: "JUNE 17, 1972."  Then: "THE WATERGATE HOTEL" A BUSBOY yawns as he clears away the remains of dinner. WAITER starts pouring Margaritas from a pitcher. A balding man in his early fifties tosses a five onto the table.  He is HOWARD HUNT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter puts down the pitcher, picks up the five, and follows the busboy out of the room. The moment the door closes behind them, GORDON LIDDY is o his feet, locking the door.  OTHER MEN are visible, putti on jackets, securing technical equipment from briefcases and bags.  They are: FRANK STURGIS, BERNARD BARKER, EUGEN MARTINEZ, VIRGILIO GONZALES, and JAMES MCCORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks his watch) Zero-one-twenty-one.  Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturgis rolls his eyes, drains his Margarita.  Liddy pull a wad of cash from his pocket, starts passing out hundred dollar bills to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in case you need to buy a cop.  But don't spend it all in one place.  We're going to do McGovern's office later tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCord shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orders from the White House, partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liddy bypasses Hunt, who is browsing a folded Spanish language paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard ... What the hell?  What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogs ... Season starts tomorrow. (off Liddy's look) It keeps me calm.  I don't like going back into the same building four times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liddy mutters something didactic in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein Kampf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translates into English) "A warrior with nerves of steel is yet broken by a thread of silk."  Nietzsche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally I'd prefer a greyhound with a shot of speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all) Remember -- listen up!  Fire team discipline is there at all times.  Keep your radios on at all times during the entire penetration.  Check yourselves.  Phony ID's, no wallets, no keys.  We rendezvous where?  The Watergate, Room 214.  When?  At zero three-hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yawohl, mein fartenfuhrer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (narrowing, waving his gun) Don't start with me, Frank, I'll make you a new asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising past them) Let's get the fuck out of here, shall we, ladies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything goes wrong, head for your homes, just sit tight -- you'll hear from me or Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside) Personally, I'll be calling the President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous chuckle as Hunt follows Liddy out the main door The rest exit through the door behind the screen. The FILM is ending.  Bob puts a hand on Earl's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And remember, Earl: Always look 'em in the eye. (to the camera) Nothing sells like sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK SCREEN as the film rattles out, followed by a RAD REPORT over the darkened room, the sounds of doors closin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five men wearing surgical gloves and  business suits, and carrying cameras and electronic surveillance equipment, were arrested today in the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee in Washington.  They were unarmed.  Nobody knows yet why they were there or what they were looking for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLES RUN - A raw November night.  We are looking throug the black iron bars of the fence towards the facade of th Executive Mansion.  A LIGHT is on in a second floor room. We move towards it through the bars, across the lawn.  De leaves blow past.  A SUBTITLE READS: "NOVEMBER 1973" A black LIMOUSINE slides up to the White House West Wing. An armed GUARD with a black DOBERMAN approaches. The window opens slightly.  The Guard peers in.  Then, he opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, General Haig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENERAL ALEXANDER HAIG gets out, walks up the steps.  He carries a manila envelope.  As he enters the White House, we hear an AUDIO MONTAGE of NEWS REPORTERS from the previous year.  The VOICES fade in and out, overlap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge John Sirica today sentenced the Watergate burglars to terms ranging from up to forty years ... The White House continues to deny any involvement ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIG enters, starts up the stairs.  The mansion is dark, silent.  Like a tomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presidential counsel John Dean testified before the Senate Watergate Committee that the scandal reaches to the highest levels ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING: A low-angle shot of Haig's spit-shined shoes movi down the long corridor of the second floor of the Residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presidential aides Haldeman and Ehrlichman were ordered to resign today ... In a stunning announcement, White House aid Alexander Butterfield revealed the existence of a secret taping system ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: on the manila envelope in Haig's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has fired the Watergate Special Prosecutor, Archibald Cox, provoking the gravest constitutional crisis in American history ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig stops at the door, quietly knocks.  No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Sirica has ordered the President to turn over his tapes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is small, austere, dominated by a portrait of LINCOLN over the fireplace.  HAIG stands in the doorway, holding the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the tapes you requested, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD NIXON is in shadow, silhouetted by the fire in th hearth.  The air-conditioning is going full blast. Haig crosses the room, opens the envelope, takes out a re of tape. Nixon sits in a small armchair in a corner.  A Uher tape recorder and a headset are on an end table at his elbow.  Next to it is a large tumbler of Scotch. Haig hands the envelope containing the tapes to Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is June twentieth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's marked.  Also there's June twenty third.  And this year -- March twenty first.  Those are the ones ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon squints at the label in the firelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the lawyers feel ... will be the basis of the ... proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon tries to thread the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon's never been any good with these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the tape on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig picks up the tape.  Then he steps to the table, reaches for the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon gestures awkwardly.  Haig turns on the lamp.  For t first time we can see Nixon's face: he hasn't slept in days, dark circles, sagging jowls, five-o'-clock shadow.  He hates the light, slurs a strange growl -- the effect o sleeping pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures) ... go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig threads the tape.  Nixon, looking at it, remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Y'know Al, if Hoover was alive none of this would've happened.  He would've protected the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover was a realist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trusted Mitchell.  It was that damn big mouth wife of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least Mitchell stood up to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like the others -- Dean, McCord, the rest ... We never got our side of the story out, Al.  People've forgotten.  I mean: "Fuck you, Mr. President, fuck you Tricia, fuck you Julie!" and all that shit, just words, but what violence!  The tear gassing, the riots, burning the draft cards, Black Panthers -- we fixed it, Al, and they hate me for it -- the double dealing bastards.  They lionize that traitor, Ellsberg, for stealing secrets, but they jump all over me 'cause it's Nixon. (repeats) ... They've always hated Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig finishes threading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say something, Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no secrets here, Al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never been a greater example to the country than you are now, sir, but ... but you need to get out more, sir, and talk to the people.  No one I know feels ... close to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks at him, moved by his concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never the buddy-buddy type, Al.  You know, "Oh I couldn't sleep last night, I was thinking of my mother who beat me" -- all that kind of crap, you know the psychoanalysis bag ... My mother ... The more I'd spill my guts, the more they'd hate me.  I'd be what ... pathetic!  If I'd bugged out of Vietnam when they wanted, do you think Watergate would've ever happened?  You think the Establishment would've given a shit about a third-rate burglary?  But did I?  Quit?  Did I pull out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares, waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, you did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right.  And there's still a helluva lotta people out there who wanna believe ... That's the point, isn't it?  They wanna believe in the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly tires of talking, rubs his hands over his fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all set, sir.  Just push this button.  Good night, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Al, men in your profession ... you give 'em a pistol and you leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night, Al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig quietly closes the door.  Nixon takes a generous slu of Scotch.  Then he looks down at the tape recorder.  He puts on the Uher headset, and hits the fast-forward butto high-speed VOICES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits stop, puts on his eyeglasses, studies the recorde for a moment.  Pushes the "play" button.  VOICES.  Barely audible at first.  Nixon leans closer, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did what?!  I don't understand.  Why'd they go into O'Brien's office in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidently to install bugs and photograph documents.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: Nixon's hideaway office in the Executive Office Building. BOB HALDEMAN, his crew-cut, hard-edged chief of staff, si across the desk, a folder open on his lap.  Nixon, at his desk, seems a healthier man than in the previous scene.  Also there are JOHN EHRLICHMAN, portly domestic advisor, and JOHN DEAN, blond, gentrified, legal counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But O'Brien doesn't even use that office.  The Democrats've moved to Miami.  There's nothing there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a fishing expedition.  Apparently it was their fourth attempt at the DNC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their fourth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible they were looking for evidence of an illegal Howard Hughes donation to the Democrats, so the Democrats couldn't make an issue of your Hughes money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contributions!  It was a legal contribution.  Who the hell authorized this?  Colson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Colson doesn't know about it; he's pure as a virgin on this one.  It's just not clear the burglars knew what they were looking for.  They were heading to McGovern's office later that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Did Mitchell know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell's out of his mind now.  Martha just put her head through a plate-glass window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Through a window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was her wrist.  And it was through a plate-glass door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, they had to take her to Bellevue.  Maybe she'll stay this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha's an idiot, she'll do anything to get John's attention.  If Mitchell'd been minding the store instead of that nut Martha we wouldn't have that kid Magruder runnin' some third-rate burglary!  Was he smoking pot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Magruder!  That sonofabitch tests my Quaker patience to the breaking point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bigger problem I see is this guy who was arrested, McCord -- James McCord -- he headed up security for the Committee to Re-Elect.  He turns out to be ex-CIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ex-CIA"?  There's no such thing as "ex-CIA," John -- they're all Ivy League Establishment.  Is he one of these guys with a beef against us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCord? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out what the hell he was doing at "CREEP."  This could be trouble.  These CIA guys don't miss a trick.  This could be a set-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUTS of all of these people arise as the scene runs McCord, Liddy, Magruder, Mitchell, Martha, Hunt, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a look to Ehrlichman) We feel the bigger concern is Gordon Liddy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fruitcake!  What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, sir, he's a nut.  He used to work here with the "Plumbers" and now he's running this Watergate caper.  You remember his plan to firebomb the Brookings using Cubans as firemen?  He wanted to buy a damned fire truck!  Magruder thinks he's just nutty enough to go off the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Liddy got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently he was using some campaign cash that was laundered for us through Mexico.  The FBI's onto it.  We could have a problem with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But it'll just be a campaign finance violation ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And if Liddy takes the rap for Watergate, we can take care of him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have time for all this shit! (to Haldeman) Just handle it, Bob!  Keep it out of the White House.  What else?  Kissinger's waiting -- he's gonna throw a tantrum again if I don't see him, threatening to quit ... again. (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir ... it turns out -- one of the people implicated is still, you see, on our White House payroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?  Not another goddamn Cuban?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  A guy named Hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stops, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt?  Howard Hunt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left his White House phone number in his hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works for Colson.  He used him on the Pentagon Papers.  We're trying to figure out when he officially stopped being a White House consultant.  After the arrest he dumped his wiretapping stuff into his White House safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Howard Hunt is working for the White House?  No shit!  This is goddamn Disneyland!  Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chappaquiddick.  You wanted some dirt on Kennedy.  Colson brought him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Hunt, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perturbed) On the list of horribles, I know what he is.  And I know what he tracks back to. (then) You say he was involved in the Plumbers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.  Colson had him trying to break into Bremer's apartment after Bremer shot Wallace, to plant McGovern campaign literature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lofty) I had nothing to do with that.  Was he ... in the Ellsberg thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you approved it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was right after the Pentagon Papers broke.  They went in to get his psychiatric records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were working on China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon has a seat, shaken.  He stares right at us, as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT'S MEN are gathered in somber silence, shari front page copies of the New York Times.  SUBTITLE READS:

dialogues.speaker: "JUNE 1971
dialogues.text: INSERT HEADLINE: "Secret Pentagon Study Details Descent into Vietnam"; "Pentagon Papers Expose Government Lies." The technique we've established of an AUDIO MONTAGE of REPORTER'S VOICES continues over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The New York Times began publishing today the first in a series of forty seven volumes of top secret Pentagon Papers relating to the war in Vietnam.  The papers reveal a systematic pattern of government lies about American involvement in the war ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon throws down the paper in disgust and attempts to fe his Irish setter, KING TIMAHOE, a biscuit, as HENRY KISSINGER paces the room, the most upset of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we are in a revolutionary situation.  We are under siege -- Black Panthers, Weathermen; The State Department under Rogers is leaking like a sieve.  And now this insignificant little shit Ellsberg publishing all the diplomatic secrets of this country will destroy our ability to conduct foreign policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeding the dog) Here, Tim ... Tim.  I'm as frustrated as you, Henry, but don't you think this one's a Democrat problem.  They started the war; it makes them look bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger lowers his voice for effect, pounds the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, how we can look the Soviets or the Chinese in the eye now and have any credibility when any traitor can leak!  Even the Vietnamese, tawdry little shits that they are, will never -- never -- agree to secret negotiations with us.  This makes you look like a weakling, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right about one thing, sir.  I spoke with Lyndon.  This Pentagon Papers business has knocked the shit out of him.  Complete collapse, massive depression.  He feels the country is lost, that you as President can't govern anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Goddamn!  How long have we had this fucking dog?!  Two years, he still doesn't come!  We need a dog that looks happy when the press is around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's photogenic.  Let's try dog bones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (end of his patience) Mr. President, the Vietnamese, the Russians ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon finally throws the biscuit at the dog, glares at Kissinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ehrlichman) Fuck it!  He doesn't like me, John! (to Kissinger) It's your fault, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your people who are leaking to the Times.  Wasn't this Ellsberg a student of yours at Harvard?  He was your idea; why are you suddenly running for cover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was, he was.  We taught a class together at Harvard.  But you know these back-stabbing Ivy League intellectuals, they can't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) No, Henry.  I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's turned into a drug fiend, he shot people from helicopters in Vietnam, he has sexual relations with his wife in front of their children.  He sees a shrink in L.A.  He's all fucked up.  Now he's trying to be a hero to the liberals ... If he gets away with it, everybody will follow his lead.  He must be stopped at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, if I might?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For three years now I've watched people in this government promote themselves, ignoring your orders, embarrassing your administration.  It makes me sick!  We've played by the rules and it doesn't work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nixon) We can prosecute the New York Times, go for an injunction ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it's not, bottom-line, gonna change a goddamn thing, John.  The question is: How do we screw Ellsberg so bad it puts the fear of God into all leakers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we link Ellsberg to the Russians?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, I like that.  The other issue is: How the hell do we plug these leaks once and for all?  Who the hell's talking to the press? (he looks directly at Henry) Henry, for two goddamn years you've put wiretaps on your own people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To protect you, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjects) To protect yourself is more like it.  The pot calling the kettle ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger throws Colson a vicious look, while Nixon ignor it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside) Who are you talking to like this, you insignificant shit ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and what do we get for it?  Gobs and gobs of bullshit, gossip, nothing!  Someone is leaking.  We've got to stop the leaks, Henry, at any cost, do you hear me?  Then we can go for the big play -- China, Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we can do this ourselves.  The CIA and the FBI aren't doing the job.  But we can create our own intelligence unit -- right here, inside the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slow move in on Nixon as he thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our own intelligence capability -- to fix the leaks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like the Plumbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it.  I like the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it legal? (a beat) I mean has anyone ever done it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Lyndon, JFK, FDR -- I mean, Truman cut the shit out of my investigation of Hiss back in '48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was illegal, what he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this kinda thing, you gotta be brutal.  A leak happens, the whole damn place should be fired.  Really.  You do it like the Germans in World War II.  If they went through these towns and a sniper hit one of them, they'd line the whole goddamned town up and say: "Until you talk you're all getting shot."  I really think that's what has to be done.  I don't think you can be Mr. Nice-guy anymore ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just whisper the word to me, sir, and I'll shoot Ellsberg myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not the Germans, sir ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellsberg's not the issue.  The Pentagon Papers aren't the issue. (almost to himself) It's the lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  Everyone in the room chews on this for a moment Mitchell, the oldest in the group, smokes on his pipe, stone-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember, John, in '48 -- no one believed Alger Hiss was a communist.  Except me.  They loved Hiss just like they loved this Ellsberg character.  East Coast, Ivy League.  He was their kind.  I was dirt to them.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they talk, a MONTAGE arises of ALGER HISS and the days of old -- the photographs of the notorious 1948 Hiss case HISS, CHAMBERS, the YOUNGER NIXON with the microfilm; a headline reading "HISS FOUND GUILTY"; TRUMAN, ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, a beaming EISENHOWER shaking Nixon's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room) And Dick beat the shit out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wouldn't have if Hiss hadn't lied about knowing Chambers.  The documents were old and out of date, like these Pentagon Papers.  The key thing we proved was that Hiss was a liar.  Then people bought it that he was a spy. (then) It's the lie that gets you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room) Hiss was protecting his wife.  I've always believed that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cryptically) When they know you've got something to protect, that's when they fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this faggot, Ellsberg, protecting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His liberal elitist friends.  His Harvard-Ph.D.-I-shit-holier-than-thou attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger waits.  Nixon acknowledges him.  The camera is moving tighter and tighter on the President.  His expression is furious, his words violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Henry -- we're gonna go your way.  Crush this Ellsberg character the same way we did Hiss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjects) There's no other choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna hit him so hard he looks like everything that's sick and evil about the Eastern Establishment. (to Colson) You and your "plumbers" are gonna find dirt on this guy -- let's see him going to the bathroom in front of the American public!  And when we finish with him, they'll crucify him!

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: ANOTHER BREAK-IN is in effect.  LIDDY in wig, thick glasses, false teeth, and THREE CUBANS (Barker, Martinez from Watergate, and de Diego, not at Watergate) are visible, moving through, smashing up the office.  In CLOS UPS, we see hands jerking open filing cabinets, pulling t drawers out of desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nixon Administration responded by filing an injunction against the New York Times to prevent further publication ... President Nixon condemned the Pentagon Papers as the worst breach of national security in U.S. history ... Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the papers, was charged today in federal court ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While this is going on, a powerful FLASHBULB keeps poppin The photographer, looking for evidence, suddenly catches his partner in the light, his startled face buried beneat a 70's wig -- HOWARD HUNT.  Hunt is pissed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you -- gimme that fucking film!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME - CLOSE on NIXON remembering Howard Hunt, as HALDEMAN looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard Hunt? ... Jesus Christ, you open up that scab ... and you uncover a lot of pus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon chooses not to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Hunt now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In hiding.  He sent Liddy to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay him?  I told him to get out of the country.  It's crazy to start ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing, Ehrlichman?  Screwing with the CIA?  I don't care how much he wants -- pay him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what are we paying him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sir, you're covered -- no one here gave orders to break into the damned Watergate.  We're clean.  It's only the Ellsberg thing, and if that comes out, it's "national security."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Security" is not strong enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a COMINT classification?  We put it on the Huston plan.  Even the designation is classified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "National Priority."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Priority?"  How about "secret, top secret"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking "sensitive."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "National security priority restricted and controlled secret."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work on it.  I say we cut ourselves loose from these clowns and that's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Nixon looks out at the Rose Garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than that.  It could be more than that.  I want Hunt paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, we've never done this before, sir ... How do we pay?  In ... hundreds? (smirks) Do you fill a black bag full of unmarked bills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) This is not a joke, John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should set up a Cuban defense fund on this; take care of all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we talk to Trini about paying these guys?  Or maybe Chotiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, keep Trini out of this.  Chotiner's too old.  And for God's sake, keep Colson out. (including Dean) It's time to baptize our young counsel.  That means Dean can never talk about it.  Attorney-client privilege.  Get to it.  And Dean -- you stay close on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, don't worry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prompted, Ehrlichman and Dean leave.  When the door close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, did I approve the Ellsberg thing?  You know, I'm glad we tape all these conversations because ... I never approved that break-in at Ellsberg's psychiatrist.  Or maybe I approved it after the fact?  Someday we've got to start transcribing the tapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You approved that before the fact, because I went over it with you.  But ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no one, of course, is going to see these tapes, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, and it's more a problem for Ehrlichman.  He fixed Hunt up with the phony CIA ID's, but ... what else does Hunt have on us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Nixon chooses not to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to turn off the FBI.  You just go to the CIA, Bob, and tell Helms that Howard Hunt is blackmailing the President.  Tell him that Hunt and his Cuban friends know too damn much, and if he goes public, it would be a fiasco for the CIA.  He'll know what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still confused) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play it tough.  That's the way they play it and that's the way we're going to play it.  Don't lie to Helms and say there's no involvement, but just say this is sort of a comedy of errors, bizarre, without getting into it.  Say the President believes it's going to open up the whole Bay of Pigs thing again.  Tell Helms he should call the FBI, call Pat Gray, and say that we wish for the sake of the country -- don't go any further into this hanky-panky, period!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bay of Pigs? ... That was Kennedy's screw-up.  How does that threaten us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do what I say, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, but ... do you think Gray'll go for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat Gray'll do anything we ask him.  That's why I appointed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll need a pretext.  He'll never figure one out for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Christ, you're right -- Gray makes Jerry Ford look like Mozart. (then) Just have Helms call him.  Helms can scare anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only problem with that, sir -- it gets us into obstruction of justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got nothing to do with justice.  It's national security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is this national security?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the President says it is.  My job is to protect this country from its enemies, and its enemies are inside the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  Haldeman is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you thought the Presidency was above this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a "moral" issue, Bob.  We have to keep our enemies at bay or our whole program is gonna go down the tubes.  The FBI is filled with people who are pissed that I put Gray in and not one of their own.  Vietnam, China, the Soviet Union: when you look at the big picture, Bob, you'll see we're doing a hell of a lotta good in this world.  Let's not screw it up with some shit-ass, third-rate burglary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to Helms. (looks at his watch) Oh, Pat asked if you're coming to the Residence for dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, not tonight.  Don't let her in here.  I have too much to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I'll talk to Helms, and, uh ... what's our press position on this Watergate thing?  What do I tell Ziegler to tell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME SCENE - NIXON takes another drink, looks up at Lincoln's portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Tell 'em what we've always told 'em!  Tell 'em anything but the goddamn truth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tape grinds on with hard-to-hear DIALOGUE, Nixon searches through a drawer in the rolltop desk next to the fireplace.  He finds a small vial of pills, fumbles with the cap.  He rips the cap off, the pills scattering on th desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins scooping them back into the bottle, his hands trembling with the effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles) Put me in this position ... Expose me like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He downs a couple of pills with the Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't they just fucking shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon takes another drink, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - JOHN F. KENNEDY looking straight at the camera.  Tanned, impeccable, confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not think the world can exist in the long run half-slave and half-free.  The real issue before us is how we can prevent the balance of power from turning against us ... If we sleep too long in the sixties, Mr. Khrushchev will "bury" us yet ... I think it's time America started moving again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON does not look well.  His clothes are baggy, and he has a slight sheen of perspiration around his lower lip.  He seems uncomfortable in his movements, robotic, falsely aggressive with his raised eyebrows and glaring demeanor. (The following essences are taken from four debates and various campaign material; in using a documentary JFK, we will be cutting around him when off-debate material is used.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... When it comes to experience, I want you to remember I've had 173 meetings with President Eisenhower, and 217 times with the National Security Council.  I've attended 163 Cabinet meetings.  I've visited fifty four countries and had discussions with thirty-five presidents, nine prime ministers, two emperors, and the Shah of Iran...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT NIXON, a year older than Dick, watches her champion through the glass booth.  The "Mona Lisa" of American politics, she projects deep admiration for, and pride in, her husband.  But now she appears perturbed by what she's seeing. A younger HALDEMAN sits watching the debates on monitors with HERB KLEIN, press secretary, and OTHERS in the Nixon circle.  Through the glass we see the CANDIDATES. MURRAY CHOTINER, campaign manager, overweight and bow-tie moves down the row of monitors holding a cigar.  He manag to drop ashes on an attractive KENNEDY STAFFER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits next to Haldeman, Nixon drones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take hydroelectric power.  In our administration, we've built more ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately) Jesus Christ, has he told them how many push-ups he can do yet?  What the hell happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just got out of the hospital, Murray, and he hasn't taken an hour off during the campaign, thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've at least gotten him a suit that fit, for Christ's sake, and slapped some makeup on him.  He looks like a frigging corpse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... When we consider the lineup of the world, we find there are 590 million people on our side, 800 million on the Communist side, and 600 million who are neutral.  The odds are 5 to 3 against us ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't do the makeup.  Said it was for queers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JFK's face is on the monitors now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kennedy doesn't look like a queer, does he? (then) He looks like a God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray, it's not a beauty contest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) What are you doing to him, Murray?  Look at him -- he's not well.  He doesn't have to debate John Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nixon, we didn't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, baby, listen, when it comes to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can win without doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... in attacking my resolve, Mr. Nixon has carefully avoided mentioning my position on Cuba ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shoot!  He's going to do it!  Here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... As a result of administration policies, we have seen Cuba go to the Communists ... eight jet minutes from the coast of Florida!  Castro's influence will spread through all of Latin America.  We must attempt to strengthen the democratic anti Castro forces in exile.  These fighters have had virtually no support from our government!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Klein, Chotiner) Sonofabitch!  He was briefed by the CIA.  He's using it against us!  He knows we can't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks, astounded, at JFK.  He fumbles his response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think ... I think ... that's the sort of very dangerous and irresponsible suggestion that ... helping the Cuban exiles who oppose Castro would, uh ... not only be a violation of international law, it would be ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closes his eyes) He's treading water.  Don't mention Khrushchev.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... an open invitation for Mr. Khrushchev to become involved in Latin America.  We would lose all our friends in Latin America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just violated national security, Dick!  Attack the bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, for one, have never believed the foreign policy of the United States should be dictated by the Kremlin.  As long as ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klein hangs his head; Chotiner shares a look with Haldema The young Kennedy staffers applaud gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sonofabitch stole it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON stands at the center of a room crowded with his MEN He is despondent, astounded.  PAT NIXON watches silently, bitter, nearly in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carried every cemetery in Chicago!  And Texas -- they had the goddamned cattle voting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final ELECTION FIGURES are coming in over the television.  They show Kennedy with a 120,000-voter margi (34.2 to 34.1 million) and run down the electoral college votes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closest election in history, Dick, and they stole it.  Sonofabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He outspent us and he still cheated.  A guy who's got everything.  I can't believe it.  We came to Congress together.  I went to his wedding.  We were like brothers, for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat leaves abruptly; she can't take it anymore.  Chotiner looks at Dick as if he were incredibly naive.  HALDEMAN a KLEIN are at a table, reams of returns before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got the figures, Dick!  The fraud is obvious -- we call for a recount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's ever contested a presidential election.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to do the counting?  The Democrats control Texas, they control Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shift 25,000 votes in two states, and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long would that take?  Six months?  A year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, what happens to the country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bastard!  If I'd called his shot on Cuba I would've won.  He made me look soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading transcript) "I feel sorry for Nixon because he does not know who he is, and at each stop he has to decide which Nixon he is at the moment, which must be very exhausting." -- Jack Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is driving in on Nixon building to a rage.  Klein knows how to get to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Nixon's a shifty-eyed, goddamn liar.  If he had to stick to the truth he'd have very little to say.  If you vote for him you ought to go to hell!" -- Harry S Truman ... That's what killed us, Dick, not Cuba -- the personality problem.  Are we gonna let these sonofabitch Democrats get away with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) You know, Herb, it's not the time ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon in close-up, inner demons moving him.  A brief IMAG of something ugly ... in Nixon.  Himself, perhaps, drench in blood, or death imagery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn Kennedy!  Goes to Harvard.  His father hands him everything on a silver platter!  All my life they been sticking it to me.  Not the right clothes, not the right schools, not the right family.  And then he steals from me!  I have nothing and he steals. (softly, lethal) And he says I have "no class."  And they love him for it.  It's not fair, Murray, it's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, you're only forty-seven.  You contest this election, you're finished.  You gotta swallow this one.  They stole it fair and square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks at him, broken-hearted.  He controls his reaction, and exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get 'em next time, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think there's gonna be a next time, Murray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chotiner picks up the corner of a campaign poster with Nixon's face on it, the name in bold below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if he's not President Nixon, he's nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON crosses the corridor which is subdued in the mornin light.  He hesitates at the door, knocks softly. PAT NIXON stirs quietly as her husband walks to her bed.  They occupy separate beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) I know ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to lose ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out to touch him.  He allows himself to be touched.  It seems that, between them, intimacy is difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes us human ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not fair, Buddy.  I can take the insults; I can take the name-calling.  But I can't take the losing.  I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to put ourselves through this again, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  We worked for it.  We earned it.  It's ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.  We know that. (then) And it's enough that we know.  Just think of the girls.  They're still young.  We never see them.  I lost my parents.  I don't want them to lose theirs; I don't want them to grow up without a mother and father ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should get out of the game.  What do you think, Buddy?  Go back to being a lawyer and end up with something solid, some money at the end of the line ... You know, I keep thinking of my old man tonight.  He was a failure, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a failure, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how much money he had in the bank when he died? (beat) Nothing.  He was so damned honest ... (then) But I miss him.  I miss him a hell of a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems about to cry.  Pat reaches out and cradles his head on her shoulder.  On his eyes we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few gas pumps in front, overlooking a dry, western, Edward Hopper landscape.  A run-down residence at the bac A large man in bloody butcher's apron, FRANK NIXON (46), crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAROLD (16), tall, handsome, walks in whistling.  He wink at RICHARD (12), who is sorting fruit in the bins.  HANNA (39), a dour but gracious Quaker woman, is behind the counter with a CUSTOMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?  He said in life there's no free ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I didn't need a free ride. (flashes a smile) I need a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Harold.  He doesn't respond well to humor. (looks at his mother, worried) Maybe if you talk to Mother she can ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather get a whipping than have another talk with her.  Anything but a talk with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is terrified Mom might overhear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's too late.  Hannah looks over, very sharp, as her customer departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard ... come with me, would you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, aloud) Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD, obediently seated, pays his Mother heed.  He see a gloomy, unsmiling child in her presence.  We sense that this is familiar territory for both.  HANNAH, very quiet, penetrating with her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Harold tests thy father's will is no reason to admire him.  Let Harold's worldliness be a warning to thee, not an example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold may have lost touch with his Bible, but thou must never lapse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, she extends her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, give it to me ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is about to plead ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not tell a lie, Richard ... The cornsilk cigarette Harold gave thee behind the store this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) I don't ... have them.  Mother ... I swear, I ... didn't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withdrawing) I see ... Well then, Richard, we have nothing more to talk about, do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fearful, blurts out) Please, Mother, it ... it was just one time, Mother, I'm ... I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I.  Thy father will have to know of thy lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) No, no!  Please, don't.  Don't tell him.  I'll never do it again.  I promise.  I promise ... (on the edge of tears) Please, mama ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I expect more from thee, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He buries his head in her skirt.  The faintest smile on Hannah's face as she pockets the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!  I'll never let you down again, Mother.  Never.  I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this shall be our little secret. (She lifts his face to hers) Remember that I see into thy soul as God sees.  Thou may fool the world.  Even thy father.  But not me, Richard.  Never me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, think of me always as your faithful dog ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNAH puts the food on the table as FRANK NIXON, sleeves rolled up, waits at the head of the table, fuming.  ARTHU (6) and DONALD (9) join RICHARD and HAROLD.  (The fifth brother, Edward, has not yet been born.)  Harold reaches for a dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare, Harold!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little laugh) I just thought, since the food was here ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't said grace yet.  Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Is it my turn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah nods.  Richard puts his hands together, trying to please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavenly Father, we humbly thank--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I'll do it.  There's a coupla things I wanna say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could thou at least remove thy apron, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This blood pays the bills, Hannah.  I'm not ashamed of how I earn my money. (clears his throat) Heavenly Father, you told Adam in the Garden, after that business with the snake, that man would have to earn his way by the sweat of his face.  Well, as far as I can tell, Father, what was true in Eden is true in Whittier, California.  So we ask you now to remind certain of our young people ... (glares at Harold) ... that the only way to get a new suit to go to the promenade with Margaret O'Herlihy, who happens to be a Catholic by the way, is to work for it. (then) Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Margaret O'Herlihy, too.  She's very pretty.  Can we pray now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys start giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is funny? (then) Pretty soon you boys are gonna have to get out there and scratch, 'cause you're not gonna get anywhere on your good looks.  Just ask those fellas ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank waves to the Hobos, now squatting and wolfing down the food.  They look up, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charity is only gonna get you so far -- even with saints like your mother around.  Struggle's what gives life meaning, not victory.  Struggle.  When you quit struggling, they've beaten you, and then you end up in the street with your hand out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank begins eating; the rest follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother was a saint, but my old man struggled his whole life.  You could call him a little man, a poor man, but they never beat him.  I always tried to remember that when things didn't go my way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTBALL MONTAGE: RICHARD (19), 150 pounds, is on the defensive line as the ball is hiked.  ("Let's get fired up!")  He gets creamed by a 200-pound offensive tackle. jumps up, no face guard, hurting, and resets.  AD LIB football chatter.  We can tell from Richard's cheap unifo that he is a substitute.  But: We go again.  And again.  Building a special RHYTHM of JU CUTS showing Nixon getting mauled each time.  He doesn't have a chance, this kid, but he has pluck.  And he comes back for more.  And more. This image of pain and humiliation should weave itself in and out of the film in repetitive currents.  As we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move down past a blizzard of balloons and confetti blo by a hotel air-conditioner to a huge "NIXON FOR GOVERNOR" banner. NIXON thrusts his arms in the air -- the twin-V salute.  The CROWD cheer wildly.  SUBTITLE READS: "CALIFORNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is slumped in an armchair, feet on a coffee table, holding a drink, going through defeat once again. HALDEMAN stares glumly at the TV.  PAT sits across the ro in grim silence. ON TV - a NEWSCASTER stands in front of a tally board wit the network logo: "Decision '62."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Kennedy has called Governor Pat Brown to congratulate him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we making a statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABC is now projecting that Brown will defeat Richard Nixon by more than a quarter of a million votes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon holds up his drink to the screen.  Moves to a piano

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Fidel Castro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to blame this on Castro, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure am.  The goddamned missile crisis united the whole country behind Kennedy.  And he was supporting Brown.  People were scared, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose Castro staged the whole thing just to beat you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, before you join the jubilation at my being beaten again, you should remember: People vote not out of love, but fear.  They don't teach that at Sunday School or at the Whittier Community Playhouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjects) I should go down and check in with our people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman leaves quickly. ON TV - GOVERNOR BROWN steps to the podium.  A band plays "Happy Days Are Here Again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back at Dick) I'm glad they don't.  You forget I had a life before California, a rough, rough life.  Life isn't always fair, Dick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon drowns her out, playing the piano (well) and singin along bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "--the skies above are clear again.  Let's sing a song of cheer again--"... Cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat turns off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues to play) Don't you want to listen to Brown's victory speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm not going to listen to any more speeches ever again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll concede in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that. (then) Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stops playing, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I've always stood by you.  I campaigned for you when I was pregnant.  During Checkers, when Ike wanted you out, I told you to fight.  This is different, Dick.  You've changed.  You've grown more ... bitter, like you're at war with the world.  You weren't that way before.  You scare me sometimes... I'm fifty years old now, Dick.  How many people's hands have I shaken -- people I didn't like, people I didn't even know.  It's as if, I don't know, I went to sleep along time ago and missed the years between... I've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves toward her awkwardly.  Pat struggles.  She goes a window, her back to him.  She is not one to enjoy "scenes."  She tends to accommodate to others to preserve an aura of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What are you saying?  What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God -- divorce? (beat) What about the girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls will grow up.  They only know you from television anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would ruin us, Buddy, our family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ruining us.  If we stay with you, you'll take us down with you. (beat) This isn't political, Dick.  This is our life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's political, for Christ's sake!  I'm political.  And you're political, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not!  I'm finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is very serious.  He sees it.  It terrifies him.  The same withdrawal he experienced from his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just what they want, Buddy.  Don't you see it?  They want to drive us apart.  To beat us.  We can't let them do it.  We've been through too much together, Buddy ... We belong together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironic) That's what you said the first time we met.  You didn't even know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARRIAGE MONTAGE: During this scene we have a series of SHOTS of their courtship -- the Whittier College campus, 1930s Los Angeles; driving in a car together; the wedding the FIRST CHILD; the Pacific NAVAL CAPTAIN underneath a palm tree; running as a first-time CONGRESSMAN with Pat; the EISENHOWER years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very tender) Oh, yes, I did.  I told you I was gonna marry you, didn't I?  On the first date ... I said it because I knew ... I knew you were the one ... so solid and so strong ... and so beautiful.  You were the most beautiful thing I'd ever seen ... I don't want to lose you, Buddy, ever...

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: Nixon seeking tenderness.  He puts a hand on her arm.  He tries gently to pull her towards him, to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, look at me ... just look at me.  Do you really want me to quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares out the window.  A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can be happy.  We really can.  We love you, Dick.  The girls and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I stop ... there'll be no more talk of divorce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment.  She finally turns her eyes to him, assenting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. (waves his hand) No more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... I'm out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never run again.  I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON stalks down the hallway, fuming.  HALDEMAN walks alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried, points to a door) Dick, you don't have to make a statement.  Herb covered it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bursts through the door into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A noisy CROWD of REPORTERS reacts, excitedly, to NIXON'S fast entry.  The smell of blood is in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON at the podium

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I believe Governor Brown has a heart, even though he believes I do not.  I believe he is a good American, even though he feels I am not.  I am proud of the fact that I defended my opponent's patriotism; you gentlemen didn't report it but I am proud I did that.  And I would appreciate it, for once, gentlemen, if you would write what I say. (time dissolve) ... For sixteen years, ever since the Hiss case, you've had a lot of fun -- a lot of fun.  But recognize you have a responsibility, if you're against a candidate, to give him the shaft, but if you do that, at least put one lonely reporter on the campaign who will report what the candidate says now and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALDEMAN glances at KLEIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I think all-in-all I've given as good as I've taken.  But as I leave you I want you to know -- just think how much you're going to be missing: you won't have Nixon to kick around anymore.  Because, gentlemen, this is my last press conference...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW REPORTERS shout questions.  There is a loud confusion, but Nixon has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grainy "NEWSREEL" treats NIXON as political history, no over.  The ANONYMOUS REPORTERS return -- YOUNG NIXON, in his Navy uniform, is campaigning in California in the 194 against Voorhis and Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can now officially write the political obituary of Richard Milhouse Nixon ... He came into being as part of the big post-war 1946 Republican sweep of the elections.  People were weary of the New Deal and FDR's big government ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of FDR, TRUMAN, and ACHESON, early Cold War imager - the Soviets, Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The United States had been a strong ally of the Soviet Union, which had lost more than twenty million people in its fight against Nazism.  But Nixon, coming from the South Pacific war, won his first term in the House by freely associating his liberal opponent, Jerry Voorhis, with Communism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of Voorhis, Hoover ... NIXON working a CROWD, standing on the tailgate of his station-wagon, debating Voorhis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Nixon, politics was war.  He didn't have opponents, he had enemies.  He didn't run against people, he ruined them ... He won his California seat in the U.S. Senate in 1950 in a vicious campaign against liberal congresswoman and movie actress, Helen Gahagan Douglas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEWSFILM of NIXON and CHOTINER at a rally with PAT.  Imag of DOUGLAS follow.  CAMPAIGN WORKERS handing out smear literature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can Helen Douglas, capable actress that she is, take up so strange a role as a foe of Communism?  Why, she's pink right down to her underwear ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nixon quickly became the Republican's attack dog.  He tore into Truman for losing Mainland China in 1949, and blamed the war in Korea on a weak foreign policy ... His speeches, if more subtle than those of his Republican ally, Joe McCarthy, were just as aggressive ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon at another rally with Pat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I promise to continue to expose the people that have sold this country down the river!  Until we have driven all the crooks and Communists and those that have helped them out of office!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of Truman, the hydrogen bomb, the Rosenbergs, Klau Fuchs, Oppenheimer, the Chinese taking over in 1949 ... Mao.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The direct result of Truman's decision is that China has gone Communist.  Mao is a monster.  Why?!  Why, Mr. Acheson?!  Who in the State Department is watching over American interests?!  Who has given the Russians the atomic bomb?! ... Today the issue is slavery!  The Soviet Union is an example of the slave state in its ultimate development.  Great Britain is halfway down the same road; powerful interests are striving to impose the British socialist system upon the people of the United States!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nixon became one of the leading lights of the notorious House Un American Activities Committee, questioning labor leaders, Spanish Civil War veterans, Hollywood celebrities ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (questioning witness) Can you tell me today the names of any pictures which Hollywood has made in the last five years showing the evils of totaliarian Communism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON surrounded by REPORTERS outside the HUAC hearing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it was the Alger Hiss case that made Nixon a household name ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IMAGES of Alger Hiss's career: clerking for Oliver Wendel Holmes; with FDR at Yalta, with Churchill, with Stalin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... One of the architects of the United Nations, intimate with FDR and Oliver Wendell Holmes, Alger Hiss was a darling of the liberals. (then) But Whittaker Chambers, a former freelance journalist, said he was a Communist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITTAKER CHAMBERS testifying before the HUAC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... If the American people understood the real character of Alger Hiss, they would boil him in oil ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hiss claimed he was being set up by Nixon and J. Edgar Hoover to discredit the New Deal's policies.  The case came down to an Underwood typewriter, and a roll of film hidden in a pumpkin patch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY IMAGE - A DETECTIVE-TYPE reaches into a hollowed-out pumpkin and pulls out microfilm.  In his congressional office, NIXON examines the film with a magnifying glass, playing to the cameras with a deadly serious mien ... Shots of MRS. HISS, the Underwood typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Years later the Freedom of Information Act revealed that the film showed a report on business conditions in Manchuria, and fire extinguishers on a U.S. destroyer.  None of these documents were classified.  Were they planted by Chambers, who seemed to have a strange, almost psychotic fixation with Alger Hiss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON points to a headline -- "HISS CONVICTED."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After two confusing trials, Hiss went to jail for perjury.  To the right wing, Nixon was a hero and a patriot.  To the liberals, he was a shameless self-promoter who had vengefully destroyed a fine man.  Eleanor Roosevelt angrily condemned him.  It was to become a pattern: you either loved Richard Nixon or hated him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief IMAGE here that will recur through-out the film.  An image of evil -- call it "The Beast."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driven by demons that seemed more personal than political, his rise was meteoric.  Congressman at 33, senator at 35, Eisenhower's vice-presidential candidate at 39.  Then came the Checkers Crisis ... Nixon was accused of hiding a secret slush fund.  About to be kicked off the ticket by Ike, he went on national television with an unprecedented appearance ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Checkers speech - NIXON, looking and sounding li Uriah Heep, pleads with the American people on TV, as PAT sits uncomfortably in an armchair nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so now what I am going to do is give this audience a complete financial history.  Everything I've earned, everything I've spent, everything I owe ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon forces a smile.  Pat is clearly in pain, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The list included their house, their Oldsmobile, Pat's Republican cloth coat, and lastly, in what was to become history -- a sentimental gift from a Texas businessman ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it was?  It was a little cocker spaniel dog.  Black and white spotted.  And ... our little girl, Tricia, the six-year-old, named it "Checkers."  And you know, the kids love that dog and we're going to keep it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-eight million people saw it.  It was shameless.  It was manipulative. (then) It was a huge success!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY REPLACEMENT - Nixon with Ike in triumph.  A clip of Eisenhower praising Nixon.  Nixon and Pat standin up to rock-throwing STUDENTS in Venezuela.  Pointing his finger at KHRUSHCHEV in the Kitchen Debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eisenhower put Nixon back on the ticket ... Responding to attacks on Truman, Acheson and the entire Democratic Party for betraying the American principles in China, Korea and elsewhere -- it was two-time Democratic presidential candidate, Adlai Stevenson, who perhaps best summed up the national unease with Richard Nixon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY - SHOTS of ADLAI STEVENSON  campaigning in '5 and '56 against IKE.  Images of JOE MCCARTHY precede.  Th HERBLOCK CARTOON of Nixon crawling out of the sewer syste Others of his cartoons follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This is a man of many masks.  Who can say they have seen his real face?  He is on an ill-will tour, representing McCarthyism in a white collar.  Nixonland has no standard of truth but convenience, and no standard of morality except sly innuendo, the poison pen, the anonymous phone call; the land of smash and grab and anything to win ... "What, ultimately, shall it profit a man if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ending with more recent SHOTS of Nixon campaigning in '60 and '62.  As the IMAGES spot out in newsreel style:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a great story of its time and, in California where it started, it has come crashing to an end.  It is too bad in a way, because the truth is, we never knew who Richard Nixon really was.  And now that he is gone, we never will ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "March of Time"-type music as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Your father stinks" ... They actually said this to Tricia.  Two girls wearing Kennedy pins.  At Chapin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A New York cocktail party.  Society DAMES.  Rich, conservative BUSINESSMEN, platters of martinis and hors d'oeuvres carried by white-gloved BLACK BUTLERS.  The fashions are Balenciaga and Courreges, tipping to the shorter hemlines; the mood is smoky and upbeat, the folks pressed into airtight packs of loud conversation. NIXON is talking to JOHN MITCHELL (54), his wife MARTHA (40's), and TWO OTHER ASSOCIATES of the law firm he has joined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anguished) She was crying when she came home. (shakes his head) She was devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor little Tricia.  Well, that's New York -- makes for a tougher animal later in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the other lawyers) I told her, her daddy couldn't even get a goddamned job in this city when I got out of Duke.  Every white-shoe lawyer firm turned me down.  Didn't have the right "look."  Hell, I couldn't even get into the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) Dick, we should catch Rocky 'fore he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELSON ROCKEFELLER, Governor of New York, dominates the room.  Big smile, horn-rimmed glasses.  Next to him is HAPPY, his new wife, much younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing) Well, he can walk in this direction, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you catch that picture of you in Newsweek last week, Dick?  You were standing in a crowd on Fifth Avenue, and you were looking straight ahead, and everyone else was looking the other way like you'd just farted or something. (laughs) It said: "Who Remembers Dick Nixon?"  I was screaming.  It was so funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was hilarious, Martha. (for the others) They were all looking the other way 'cause they were waiting for the light to change.  I called AP on that -- typical of the press in this country, they wouldn't correct it.  That or they print the retraction right next to the girdle ads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've read some very nice things about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts her hand on Nixon's arm) Maybe where you come from.  But where I come from, Dick Nixon is as misunderstood as a fox in a henhouse.  And you know why? (they all wait) Because, honey, they all think your smile and your face are never in the same place at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me -- we gotta work on that, sweetie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guiding Dick away) Someone freshen Martha's drink.  I think she's down a quart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, zippety-fucking-doo-dah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell moves Nixon away towards the Rockefeller GROUP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dick.  She's a little tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean smashed!  She called up at midnight last week.  Talking a bunch of crap.  Pat can't stand her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a thing she does.  She talks at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talks all day, too!  How the hell can you put up with her, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) What the hell -- I love her.  And she's great in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rockefeller holds court, not immediately noticing Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There are no guarantees in politics.  I'm going to roll the dice with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY KISSINGER (40's), intense, holds a martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if a Rockefeller can't become President of the United States, what's the point of democracy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point of democracy is that even the son of a grocer can become president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you came damn close, too, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rocky clutches Dick, who doesn't like to be touched:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howya doin'!  New York treating you okay?  I'm sorry I haven't been able to see you at all--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting off the apology) Well enough.  You're looking "happy," Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a look to Happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Happy! (introduces his new wife) Dick Nixon ... You remember him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
