dialogues.text: Hi, Happy.  Well, you're obviously making him happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repartee, Dick -- very good.  Hey, I feel ten years younger!  It makes a helluva difference, let me tell ya!  How's the lawyer life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never made so much money in my life.  But my upbringing doesn't allow me to enjoy it.  I did get to argue a case before the Supreme Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won or lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OTHERS are pressing in on Rockefeller, who is obviously t "star" of the party, so there is pressure to talk fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But being out of the game gives me time to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write.  You know, a book.  I'm calling it "Six Crises."  It's a good thing, Rocky -- take some time off to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking another hand) Hiya, fellow ... What were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "crises"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Checkers" of course, Hiss, Ike's heart attack, Venezuela, the Kitchen Debate, and Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you got a crisis syndrome.  Aren't you exaggerating a bit, Dick?  Call it three-and-a-half, maybe four ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs awkwardly) Let's wait and see how you survive your first crisis, Rocky ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know: how the voters are gonna play your divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rockefeller, who still clutches the visibly uncomfortable Nixon, gives him a squeeze before finally releasing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about it, fella, and I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About to rejoin his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in any case, Rocky, I'll send you my book.  "Six Crises."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha predicting -- your boy Goldwater going to split the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some say you are, Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Republican Party was never home to extremists.  You should know better.  This guy's as stupid as McCarthy, and McCarthy never did you any good in the long run, now did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  It lands home on Dick.  Rockefeller turns to Kissinger, who's been listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know Henry Kissinger -- he's down from Harvard.  On my staff, foreign policy whiz ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes hands) No, but I liked your book on nuclear weapons.  We have similar views on the balance of power ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's wonderful.  So get me this "crisis" thing, Dick; I'll be glad to take a look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raps Nixon one more time on the shoulder and moves of into a waiting GROUP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as the old alliances crumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally someone who's noticed!  I'm a great admirer of yours, too, Mr. Nixon.  You are an unusual politician.  We share a mutual idol -- "Six Crises" sounds like a page from Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill, DeGaulle, Disraeli.  They all went through the pain of losing power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) But they all got it back again, didn't they? (proffering a card) We should have lunch sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON and MITCHELL move to the edges of the PARTY, which now diminishing.  They bypass PAT, who is absently starin off in conversation with MARTHA and SEVERAL OTHER LADIES who lunch ... Nixon looks back at ROCKEFELLER leaving -- KISSINGER hovering near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething) Rocky's full of shit!  No way he's going to get nominated west of the Hudson with a new wife.  He's gonna be drinking Scotches in retirement at some goddamn country club with the rest of the Republicans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes to show you all the moolah in the world can't buy you a brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snags a drink from a passing tray) Well, he seems to have bought Kissinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jewboy's a Harvard whore with the morals of an eel -- sells himself to the highest bidder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brays loudly) You're the one who should be in politics, John.  You're tougher than I am.  You never crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here; it's too painful.  I hate it. (then) We went bowling last weekend.  Next weekend we're going to the zoo.  Whoever said there was life after politics was full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make some money, Dick, prove yourself to the Wall Street crowd and let Goldwater and Rockefeller take the fall against Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  John, I'm in hell. (then) I'll be mentally dead in two years and physically dead in four.  I miss -- I don't know -- making love to the people.  I miss -- entering a room.  I miss -- the pure "acting" of it.  John, I've got to get back in the arena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Pat glancing over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOTLIGHT on a sexy Studebaker car of the era.  A DRUM ROLL, and suddenly out of the various apertures of the ca pop six half-naked HOSTESSES doing the twist.  Wild cheer The ANNOUNCER describes the new gimmicks on the car (AD LIB) as we swing to reveal NIXON, looking uncomfortable i a Stetson cowboy hat shaking hands with AUTOGRAPH SEEKERS and car buffs, posing for cheese-cake photographs.  A banner behind him reveals: "Dallas Welcomes Studebaker Dealers." The Studebaker GIRLS are fanning out through the sales booths, whistling, swinging whips, as a large man in a Stetson, JACK JONES, accompanied by a suave-looking Cuban born businessman, TRINI CARDOZA, breaks through the autograph hounds to rescue Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough now, let him be.  He's just like you and me, folks, just another lawyer ... Let's go, let's go, break it up ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving Nixon out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jack.  You sure throw a helluva party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party ain't started yet, Dick.  Got these gals coming over to the ranch later for a little private "thing," y'know ... There's some fellows I want you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, Trini and I have an early plane.  We were hoping to get back to New York in time for ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be okay, Dick; these guys are interesting ... real quiet.  And the girls are, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, it's not every day we Texans get to entertain the future President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you said Jack, I'm just a New York lawyer now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles, with a look to Trini) We'll see about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New FANS circle up, their WIVES giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Nixon could you sign ...?  My wife and I think you are just the greatest.  Please run again ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More fans flood in, circling him.  On Trini and Jack watching this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An entire LONGHORN STEER turns on a spit in a large barbecue pit, basted by black SERVANTS.  We see a sprawli Spanish-style RANCH HOUSE in the countryside.  The parkin area looks like a Cadillac dealership.  The CROWD is a mixture of CORPORATE EXECUTIVES, CUBANS, and COWBOY-TYPES some WIVES. TRINI is talking to TWO of the DANCERS, nodding his head NIXON'S direction.  They look, and smile at him. Across the lawn, Nixon smiles back awkwardly as JACK JONE nudges him.  They both eat steaks and corncobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know for a fact that the one with the big tits is a Republican, and she'd do anything for the Party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quite pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name's Sandy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trini joins them, bringing the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Jack, this looks like a pretty straight-forward transaction to me, but we should get into it soon -- just take a few minutes, maybe up at the house ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Trini, coming up) He's all business, ain't he, Trini? (to Dick) Dick, we could've had our own goddamn lawyers handle this deal.  We brought you down here 'cause we wanted to talk to you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, this is Teresa, and this is Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi ... Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A walk-in stone fireplace dominates the room; the heavy beams hung with black wrought-iron candelabras.  Thick cigar smoke impregnates the air; the crowd has substantially thinned to the heaviest hitters.  The MEN, now in shirt-sleeves, drink from bottles of bourbon. A man -- MITCH -- emerges from one of the side rooms with DANCER. Off to the side in a semi-private alcove, SANDY, the dancer, tries to make conversation, but NIXON is showing her pictures of his kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Julie ... and that's Tricia.  She, uh, reminds me a little bit of you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("interested") Oh yeah ... she really is ... wholesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trini interjects, trying to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's up?  ... Uh, I get the feeling Sandy really likes you, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that name, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you two disappear in the bedroom in there.  Come back in half an hour ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... Trini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trini smiles and, leaving Dick the playing field, vanishe Sandy, feeling the vacuum, holds Nixon's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say?  Do you like me, Mister Vice President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon swallows hard, blushing now.  He sweats, very uncomfortable with this intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (croaks) Yes, of course.  But ... uh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief IMAGE flashes by -- beastlike, offensive, unworth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I don't really know you yet, Sandy ... What do you like?  I mean, what kind of clothes do you like?  Do you like blue ... red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like satin, I like pink ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of, uh ... music do you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like jazz ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Guy Lombardo ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elvis I like, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, he's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy puts her hands on his face and head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it depends on what I'm doing to the music, Dick ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, is your mother ... still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she lives in Dallas ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be very attractive.  Would she like an autograph?  She might remember me ... Where's Trini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking around desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.  The crowd has thinned further to a hard-core doze The last man -- Mitch -- comes from the inner bedrooms, zipping up, the Servants chasing out the straggling girls Another round of drinks is served.  The cigars are out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, Kennedy's pissed Cuba away to the Russians.  And he don't know what the hell he's doing in Vietnam.  These are dangerous times, Dick, especially for business ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CUBAN in an Italian suit, one part sleazy, another part dangerous, steps from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know what you tried to do for Cuba, Mr. Nixon.  If you'd been elected president in '60, we know Castro'd be dead by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON shares a look with TRINI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I tried.  I told Kennedy to go into Cuba.  He heard me and he made his decision.  I appreciate your sentiments.  I've heard them from many fine Cuban patriots, but it's nothing I can do anything about.  Now, it's a long drive back to Dallas tonight, and Trini and I have got an early flight tomorrow to New York ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Dick, these boys want you to run. (the "boys" mutter in unison) They're serious.  They can deliver the South and they can put Texas in your column.  That would've done it in '60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if Kennedy dumps Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sonofabitch Kennedy is coming back down here tomorrow.  Dick, we're willing to put up a shitpot fulla money to get rid of him -- more money'n you ever dreamed of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna beat Kennedy in '64 with all the money in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose Kennedy don't run in '64?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks at him.  A subconscious IMAGE again -- something slimy, reptilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are dangerous times, Mr. Nixon.  Anything can happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause.  Nixon gathers together his papers and briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well ... Gentlemen, I promised my wife.  I'm out of politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insolent smile) You just came down here for the weather, right, Mr. Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came down here to close a deal for Studebaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about '68, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years, Trini?  In politics, that's an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your country needs you, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon shakes his hand, departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, my country isn't available right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD is waiting for Air Force One.  People hold banner signs: "Dallas Loves JFK," "We Love You Jackie." A Cadillac pulls up at the far corner of the tarmac.  NIX gets out with CARDOZA.  They walk toward a small executiv PLANE. Nixon pauses, looks up.  He feels something ominous in th air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trini, let's get out of here fast.  Go check on the pilot, or they'll hold us up till he's out of the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Trini hurries off to the plane, Nixon takes one last look up at his fate written in the soft white clouds over Dallas.  As we:

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY
dialogues.text: JOHN KENNEDY coming off the plane at Love Field with JACKIE, waving to the crowd.  The sound of a rushing, monstrous engine.  Then wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits, subdued, in an armchair in a small study, caught between the fire in the grate, the TELEVISION imag of the assassination, and the phone call he's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low-key) Look, Edgar, these guys were really strange, I mean, y'know ... extremists, right-wing stuff, Birchers ... Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon listens for several beats.  PAT, smoking nervously, watches from another chair.  Newspapers are strewn all around. DOCUMENTARY IMAGES on the TV show a grieving JACKIE, BOBB TEDDY and the TWO CHILDREN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see ... Oswald's got a Cuba connection ... to Castro?  I see.  A real Communist.  That makes sense.  Thank you, Edgar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.  It's evident he's still puzzled, but wants believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover says this Oswald checks out as a beatnik-type, a real bum, pro-Castro ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV images of BOBBY KENNEDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, you should call Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want me at the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at TV) De Gaulle's gonna be there.  And Macmillan.  And Adenauer. Nixon can't not be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then call him.  I'm sure it was an oversight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's his way.  He hates me.  Him and Teddy.  They always hated me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've lost a brother.  You know what that means, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon sighs, watches the TV -- images of a touch football game in Hyannis Port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR NIXON (7) cries in pain.  RICHARD (12) helps FRANK his father, hold him on the bed as a DOCTOR twists a long needle into the base of Arthur's spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!  Please!  Make it STOP!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's eyes roll onto Richard for help, Richard can't bear it, pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK comes down the narrow stairs, shocked, fighting tears.  HANNAH sits reading her Bible.  The BOYS linger nervously around their made-up cots in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobs) The doctors are afraid the little darling is going to die ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR laps at some tomato gravy on toast, which makes hi happy.  His face is angelic, as if he were getting better HANNAH feeds him, cleans his lips with a napkin, as RICHA sits close by, squeezing Arthur's hand, puzzled by it all FLASHES run through his head -- Arthur sitting on his lap learning to read; Dick swinging Arthur by his arms.  DON and HAROLD are also there.  The Doctor has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Thank you, Mama, I feel better ... I'm sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing the food) We'll let thee rest now, my little angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tucks him in.  He yawns.  The brothers are awkward, ready to leave.  Arthur turns his loving eyes on Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, don't you think ... I should say a prayer before I sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is awkward, stutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nearly cracking) Yes, Arthur, I do ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I should die before I wake, I pray the Lord my soul to take ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips off, into a coma. Richard watches, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD runs to his mother, HANNAH, who is coming down th stairs with FRANK.  She seems very shaken, but quiet, off in another world.  The moment Richard reaches her, throwi his arms around her skirt, she snaps him back.  A harsh, angry voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! ... No.  Don't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is shocked as his mother sweeps by in her private grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME NIXON - his face lost in the silence of the memory The television SOUNDS fade back in alongside PAT'S voice. TV IMAGE - LYNDON JOHNSON being sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... if I'd been president, they never would have killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat is bewildered by the statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick?  Are you going to call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, absent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back at the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) No ... I'll go through Lyndon.  We'll be invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We flash suddenly to Kennedy's head being blown apart.  Then back to Johnson as we:

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: IMAGE - CLOSE on LYNDON JOHNSON announcing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... accordingly, I shall not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your president ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNAH NIXON, in her seventies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Johnson's  withdrawal resurrects Richard Nixon as a strong Republican candidate against the war.  His mother, Hannah Nixon, just before her death last year, commented on her son's chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nixon, do you think your son will ever return to politics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he has a choice.  He was always a leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he'd make a great president, Mrs. Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... if he's on God's side, yes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTERS flock outside the building as NIXON and his GRO exit their car, trying to ignore the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON enters, ebullient, with MITCHELL, HALDEMAN, ZIEGLER taking off their winter coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Dick, never seen anything like it!  Even the goddamn Times is saying you got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vietnam's gonna put you in there this time, chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the press this time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we got the "big mo"!  We're back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  You've decided?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn.  PAT is in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you planning to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ... haven't announced anything ... uh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's walking away, cold.  Dick follows, with a look to h men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, wait ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need her, Dick -- in '60 she was worth five, six million votes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry -- I'll use the old Nixon charm on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) The old Nixon charm?  Who could resist that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON enters.  PAT is mechanically taking his identical gray suits from the closet and laying them on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be going ... the primaries are soon, aren't they?  New Hampshire ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love you, Buddy.  They need you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want them to love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you out there.  It won't be like last time.  The war's crippled the Democrats.  I can win ... We deserve it.  Yeah, it's ours, Buddy -- at last.  Nobody knows better than you.  Frank Nixon's boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat slows her packing.  Nixon takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what Mom said?  We're not like other people, we don't choose our way.  We can really change things, Buddy.  We've got a chance to get it right.  We can change America!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, looks at him, feels his surge of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was our dream, too, Buddy, together ... always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want this, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This.  Above all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you'll be happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The briefest smile opens her face.  He takes the inch, presses in, hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... you know it!  Yes ... I will.  Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his embrace) Then I'll be there for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exultant) You're the strongest woman I ever met.  I love you, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just ask for one thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you ... would you kiss me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does so with all the earnestness he is capable of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON, fielding questions, is on a small stage, surrounde by a STUDIO AUDIENCE in a semi-circle.  A mike is around his neck, no separation from the people.  PAT sits behind him, a campaign smile painted on.  Nixon is visible to us on TV monitors inside an engineer's booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never question Senator Kennedy's patriotism.  But going around the country promising peace at any price is exactly what the North Vietnamese want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.  Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the TV director) Cue the crowd.  Go to the woman's group.  Get the bald guy, he's great ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, unlike Senator Kennedy, have a plan to end the war.  But not for peace at any price, but peace with honor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J. EDGAR HOOVER (60's), short and fat, covered with steam room sweat, looks like a Roman emperor, as he watches television intermittently, taking pictures of CLYDE TOLSO (50's), his long-time friend and associate.  Tolson has a towel around his waist and one over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) What do you think this plan is, Edgar?  A nuclear attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying, Clyde.  Always has.  That's why Nixon's always been useful.  Hold still.  And take your hand off your hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOAQUIN, a very young, near-naked Hispanic boy, comes in with refreshments: orange slices, fruit, and pastel drink with parasols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RON ZIEGLER checks his scripts as NIXON continues on the other side of the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) Who's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Negro.  We gotta have a Negro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK MAN appears on the monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nixon ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made a career out of smearing people as Communists.  And now you're building your campaign on the divisions in this country.  Stirring up hatred, turning people against each other ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ziegler and HALDEMAN are apoplectic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck's he doing?  He's making a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut him off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't cut him off!  This isn't Russia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Man turns to the studio audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want a real dialogue with the American people.  This whole thing's been staged.  These aren't real people.  You're just a mouthpiece for an agenda that is hidden from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Go to commercial!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no commercials.  You bought the whole half-hour, baby ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Man is walking down the aisle toward Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impassioned) When are you going to tell us what you really stand for?  When are you going to take the mask off and show us who you really are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Nixon's upper lip, sweating. Haldeman watches intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a high hard one, chief.  Park it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon gathers himself, looks firmly at the Black Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there are divisions in this country ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who made them -- you made them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but I didn't create them.  The Democrats did!  If it's a dialogue you want, you're more likely to get it from me than from the people who are burning down the cities!  Just think about that ... The great Doctor King said the same things.  You know, young man, who a great hero is -- Abraham Lincoln.  Because he stood for common ground, he brought this country together ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience applauds.  Haldeman punches Ziegler's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that man! (then) Fire the sonofabitch who let that agitator in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Okay, go to the little girl.  Can he see the little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right down front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you can see her, but there's a little girl sitting down here with a sign.  Could you hold that up, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bag the guy.  Take the sign!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Camera cuts to a LITTLE GIRL holding a hand-lettered sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign has on it three simple words: "Bring us together!"  That is what I want, and that is what the great silent majority of Americans want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience loves it.  APPLAUSE signs light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts over) And that's why I want to be president.  I want to bring us together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a lizard, HOOVER eyes JOAQUIN, the Hispanic boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... give me a break, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know me.  I'm one of you, I grew up a stone's throw from here on a little lemon ranch in Yorba Linda ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimics) It was the poorest lemon ranch in California, I can tell you that.  My father sold it before they found oil on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the poorest lemon ranch in California, I can assure you.  My father sold it before they found oil on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimics) But it was all we had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it was all we had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're new.  What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joaquin, Mr. Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover selects an orange slice, puts one end between his teeth.  Wiggles it.  Joaquin bends over, bites off the other end.  Tolson looks peeved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father built the house where I was born with his own hands.  Oh, it wasn't a big house ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn this crap off, Clyde.  It's giving me a headache ... You may go, Joaquin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a drink off Joaquin's tray as Clyde turns off th TV.  Joaquin vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him tomorrow, Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar, think twice.  He works in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Joaquin, you idiot.  Nixon.  Did you hear what he said in Oregon?  About me having too much power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's between Nixon and a Kennedy again, Edgar ... Who do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kennedy -- never.  He'll fry in hell for what he did to me.  But Nixon doesn't know that, which is why I'm gonna have to remind him he needs us a helluva lot more'n we need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOROUGHBREDS explode out of the chutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private box just above the finish line.  HOOVER raises his binoculars, watching the race.  He is wearing a white tropical suit, Panama hat, white shoes.  CLYDE is dressed similarly. JOHNNY ROSELLI, white hair, deep tan, sharp dresser, sits with him in the box, spots someone ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy's on his way up ... I met him years ago.  In Havana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TRACK: TWO HORSES are in a terrific stretch drive. HOOVER watches impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) And down the stretch they come!  It's Sunday's Chance Son and Olly's Boy duelling for the lead ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: OLLY'S BOY puts a nose in front of SUNDAY'S CHANCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's folding, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TRACK: Sunday's Chance is tiring, falling behind Olly's Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: On Olly's Boy bandaged front legs.  Then, Olly Boy right foreleg snaps.  It sounds like a rifle shot. Olly's Boy goes down over his shoulder.  The JOCKEY is thrown across the track. The CROWD is stunned.  Sunday's Chance wins easily. Hoover turns to Roselli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit extreme, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the drama. (gestures to the crowd) The crowd loves that shit.  Hey!  There's Randolph Scott.  You might like that guy, friend of mine.  Wanna meet him?  Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOUTING and CHEERS behind them.  They turn.  NIXON is making his way down the aisle, waving to the crowd.  He i followed by HALDEMAN. Hoover passes Roselli a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Johnny.  Cash this for me, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a two-dollar bet, Edgar.  You got thousands coming on this ... what the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, just cash it, Johnny.  And don't swear around me ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Roselli crosses Nixon, who enters the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar, wonderful to see you.  Clyde ... hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I've just had a bit of luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The management of Del Mar is saddened to announce that Olly's Boy will have to be destroyed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groans from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you?  Are you going to win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should ask Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) ... little Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you walk with me down to the paddock?  I'd like to look at the horses for the eighth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we just talk here?  I've got the police chiefs in San Diego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to spare you an embarrassment.  Johnny Roselli is on his way back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roselli?  Johnny Roselli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Your old friend from Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never met the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you've been very careful not to.  That's why I'm concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon glances at Hoover.  Hoover smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving with NIXON, HOOVER and TOLSON along the rail outsi the walking ring.  FBI AGENTS have cleared a circle aroun them.  The HORSES for the next race are being saddled.  Nixon waves to PATRONS of the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll win the nomination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be '60 all over again, Edgar.  Bobby's got the magic, like a goddamn rock star.  They climb all over each other just to touch his clothes!  He'll ride his brother's corpse right into the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) If things remain as they are ... He's got the anti-war vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or he'll steal it like his brother.  He's a mean little sonofabitch, Edgar ... He had the IRS audit my mother when she was dying in a nursing home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) ... Somebody should shoot the little bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna fight just as dirty as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Use his women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Any information you have, Edgar.  The sonofabitch is not gonna steal from me again!  Can you back me up on this?  Can I count on your support?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) I look at it from the point of view that the system can only take so much abuse.  It adjusts itself eventually, but at times there are ... savage outbursts.  The late "Doctor" King for example.  A moral hypocrite screwing women like a degenerate tomcat, stirring up the blacks, preaching against our system ... (shakes his head) Sometimes the system comes close to cracking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover stop in front of a huge GELDING, pats his muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already had one radical in the White House.  I don't think we could survive another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon feels uncomfortable.  Images, vague, disturbing.  Even the nostrils on the horse seem to be emitting a devil's fire, and the noises of the snorting animal magni ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Yeah, well, as I said, Edgar ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (precisely) You asked if you could count on my support ... As long as I can count on yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old queen did it on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME SCENE - NIXON listens as the tape rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't protecting me.  He was putting me on notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  That he knew Johnny Roselli?  Hoover knew a lot of gangsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Roselli wasn't just any gangster.  He was the gangster who set up Track 2 in Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON and HALDEMAN are alone.  The lights are on.  Nixon' had a couple of drinks.  The talk is a little looser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) I don't understand.  Track 2's Chile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chile, Congo, Guatemala, Cuba.  Wherever's there's a need for an Executive Action capability, there's a Track 2.  In Cuba, Track 1 was the Bay of Pigs invasion.  Track 2 ... it was our idea. (stands) We felt the invasion wouldn't work unless we got rid of Castro.  So we asked ourselves -- who else wants Castro dead?  The Mafia, the money people.   So we put together Track 2 ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images begin to project from that long-ago time.  A YOUNG NIXON.  Macho Cuban "Freedom Fighters" in the Keys and Guatemala.  The CIA, the MOB -- including JOHNNY ROSELLI. FAT CATS and CASINO BOSSES shaking hands with young Nixon on his visit in the 40's.  A Rum and Coca-Cola SONG plays

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) The first assassination attempt was in '60, just before the election.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) Before?!  Eisenhower approved that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't veto it. (then) I ran the White House side.  The mob contact was Johnny Roselli. (then) One of the CIA guys was that jackass, Howard Hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not just Hunt.  Frank Sturgis, all those Cubans.  All of them in the Watergate.  They were involved in Track 2 in Cuba. (then) Hunt reported to my military aide.  But I met with him several times as Vice President.  That's what worries the shit out of me.  I don't know how much Hunt knows.  Or the Cubans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  You wanted Castro dead.  Everybody wanted Castro dead.  If Hunt and the others are CIA, why don't we just throw this back in the CIA's lap?  Let Richard Helms take the fall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Because ... because Dick Helms knows too much ... If anyone in this country knows more than I do, it's Hoover and Helms!  You don't fuck with Dick Helms!  Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  But why, if Kennedy is so clean in all this, didn't he cancel Track 2?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he didn't even know about it.  The CIA never told him, they just kept it going.  It was like ... it had a life of its own.  Like ... a kind of "beast" that doesn't even know it exists.  It just eats people when it doesn't need 'em anymore. (drops back in his chair) Two days after the Bay of Pigs, Kennedy called me in.  He reamed my ass ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY INTERCUT: Brief, moving, live-action image of JOHN KENNEDY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he'd just found out about Track 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never told him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I didn't want him to get the credit.  He said I'd stabbed him in the back.  Called me a two-bit grocery clerk from Whittier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon's face expresses the deep hurt of that insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the last time I ever saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IMAGE - the "Beast" - an image of Kennedy perverted, his head blown off ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they didn't tell Kennedy about Track 2, how did Hoover find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had us bugged.  Christ, he had everybody bugged.  Yeah, he was gonna support me in '68, but he was also threatening me. (then) That was Hoover: he'd give you the carrot, but he'd make damn sure the stick went right up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE of chaos in the pantry.  The camera i jostled.  Women screaming.  A man is being wrestled to th floor. ROBERT KENNEDY lies there, mortally wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I saw Bobby lying there on the floor, his arm outstretched like that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME SCENE - NIXON and HALDEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... his eyes staring ... (then) I knew I'd be president. (beat) Death paved the way, didn't it?  Vietnam.  The Kennedys.  It cleared a path through the wilderness for me.  Over the bodies ... Four bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman corrects him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean two ... two bodies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean two ... two bodies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME SCENE - NIXON takes a slug of Scotch, then he rubs the bridge of his nose, looks up at the portrait of Lincoln.  A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurs, softly to Lincoln) How many did you have?  Hundreds of thousands ... Where would we be without death, huh, Abe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stands, steadies himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Who's helping us?  Is it God?  Or is it ... Death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lunar landscape -- barren, scorched, silent.  Suddenly, violent, desperate coughing. HAROLD NIXON (23) is doubled over the railing, a long string of bloody mucus hanging from his lips.  He is shockingly emaciated -- the last stages of tuberculosis.  HANNAH NIXON, in background attending TWO OTHER PATIENTS, looks on at Harold. RICHARD (19) hurries out of the cabin with a cotton cloth He holds Harold until he stops heaving.  Then, he wipes h mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasps) ... that was a whopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard carefully folds the cloth, drops it into a metal container that is already full of them.  He stands there, helpless, a solemn boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panting) Hey ... you'll be able to do it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to law school.  Mom and Dad'll be able to afford it now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard looks at him in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom expects great things from you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold ... can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold throws a loving arm around Richard, who tenses.  W sense that Harold in some way could have helped Richard, taught him to laugh a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a gentle smile) Relax, Dick, it's just me ... The desert's so beautiful, isn't it? (then) I want to go home, Dick.  Time to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) You're not gonna quit on me, are you, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold looks out over the landscape.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD sits staring into the fire.  He still wears his black suit from Harold's funeral.  HANNAH enters quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves closer, casting a shadow over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gift, Richard.  This law school is a gift from your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter) Did he have to die for me to get it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's meant to make us stronger. (kneels) Thou art stronger than Harold ... stronger than Arthur.  God has chosen thee to survive ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about happiness, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou must find thy peace at the center, Richard.  Strength in this life.  Happiness in the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON RICHARD NIXON (55) in his prime.  A profile of his fac as the vast crowd goes berserk.  Nixon absorbs the adoration: at last, he has arrived.  He looks down at someone in the audience.  Points, smiles, waves. Then he steps forward, thrusts his arms in the air -- the twin-V salute.  The cheers rattle the hall as PAT and the DAUGHTERS join him, followed by Vice President SPIRO AGNE and his FAMILY.  Nixon puts his arm around Pat.  She wave The crowd is on its feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately, to Pat) Now tell me you didn't want this, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat smiles back at him, caught up in it.  Then she kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON addresses the DELEGATES (a composite of Nixon speeches).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for some honest talk about the problem of law and order in the United States.  I pledge to you that the current wave of violence will not be the wave of the future!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vast APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 1. Civil war.  Tanks in the streets of DETROIT.  2. A BLACK PANTHER safe-house in flames surrounded by FBI AGENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The long dark night for America is about to end ... Let us begin by committing ourselves to the truth -- to find the truth, to speak the truth.  And to live the truth ... A new voice is being heard across America today: it is not the voice of the protestors or the shouters, it is the voice of a majority of Americans who have been quiet Americans over the past few years ... a silent majority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 3. GEORGE WALLACE whips a DIXIE CRO into a frenzy.  4. The WOUNDED KNEE SIEGE is underway - F AGENTS and LOCAL MILITANTS pour fire in on the INDIAN MILITANTS.  5.  The YIPPIE DEMONSTRATORS outside the CHICAGO DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION.  Chicago POLICE wade in wi nightsticks, tear gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the podium) Who are they?  Let me tell you who they are -- they're in this audience by the thousands, they're the workers of America, they're white Americans and black Americans ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut among the DELEGATES, seeking to show the face of t populace that is torn by civil war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... they are the Mexican Americans and the Italian Americans, they're the great silent majority, and they have become angry, finally; angry not with hate but angry, my friends, because they love America and they don't like what's happened to America these last four years!  We will regain respect for America in the world.  A burned American library, a desecrated flag ... Let us understand: North Vietnam cannot defeat or humiliate the United States.  Only Americans can do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This brings the house down!  As we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 6. CHICAGO is now a full-scale POLI RIOT.  The COPS have lost all control, swinging nightstic wildly, breaking heads, dozens of arrests. Closing on NIXON at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's face it.  Most Americans today, in a crisis of spirit, are simply fed up with government at all levels.  All the Great Society activists are lying out there in wait, poised to get you if you try to come after them: the professional welfareists, the urban planners, the day-carers, the public housers.  The costly current welfare system is a mess, and we are on the brink of a revolt of the lower middle class.  The bottom line is -- no work, no welfare.  Our opponents have exaggerated and over-emphasized society as the cause of crimes.  The war on poverty is not a war on crime, and it is no substitute for a war on crime. (pause) I say to you tonight we must have a new feeling of responsibility, of self discipline.  We must look to renew state and local government!  We must have a complete reform of a big, bloated federal government.  The average American is just like the child in the family.  You give him some responsibility and he is going to amount to something.  If you make him completely dependent and pamper him, you are going to make him soft, and a very weak individual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I begin with the proposition that freedom of choice in housing, education and jobs is the right of every American.  On the other hand, I am convinced that while legal segregation is totally wrong, forced integration of housing or education is just as wrong!  We simply have to face the hard fact that the law cannot go beyond what people are willing to support.  This was true as far as Prohibition was concerned.  It is far more true with regard to education and housing ... Yet those of us in public service know -- we can have full prosperity in peace time ... Yes, we can cut the defense budget.  We can reduce conventional forces in Europe.  We can restore the national environment.  We can improve health care and make it available more fairly to all people.  And yes, we can have a complete reform of this government.  We can have a new American Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 7. The young CHICAGO DEMONSTRATORS are chanting rebelliously at POLICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole world is watching!  The whole world is watching!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 8. A B-52 unloads BOMBS and NAPALM over jungle. SUBTITLE READS: "LAOS - SECRET BOMBING CAMPAIGN, 1969-70;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are blazing late with war talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a small paneled room, the talk is angry: BILL ROGERS, Secretary of State, MEL LAIRD, Defense Secretary, to one side; KISSINGER with HAIG, seen earlier, but now Kissinger's assistant, to the other side of the desk, as NIXON listens; HALDEMAN takes notes.  ZIEGLER looks on.  Though a stand-up chart displays a large map of Cambodia' border with South Vietnam, we may note there are no military personnel in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It'd be a disaster for us, Mr. President.  There's a lot of sympathy out there for Cambodia, a tiny, neutral Buddhist nation.  There'd be protests in the streets, right out on your front lawn ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Building this Cambodian army up will be harder even than the Vietnamese army.  They have no tradition of ... The government there would collapse if we ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon's eyes narrow, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying, "Do nothing" -- that's what you're saying.  The same old shit.  Well, that's not good enough.  I'm sick of being pushed around by the Vietnamese like some pitiful giant.  They're using our POWs to humiliate us.  What we need now is a bold move to Cambodia; go right after the VC base camps, make 'em scream.  That's what I think.  You, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pivotal moment for Henry.  Nixon is clearly scrutinizin Kissinger, who glances at his rivals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, most of my staff have weighed in against this "incursion."  They believe it will fail to achieve anything fundamental militarily, and will result in crushing criticism domestically ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I didn't ask what your staff thinks, Henry.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) What I think is ... they're cowards.  Their opposition represents the cowardice of the Eastern Establishment.  They don't realize as you do, Mr. President, that the Communists only respect strength, and they will only negotiate in good faith if they fear the "madman," Richard Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon lets a dark smile curl one side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly!  We've got to take the war to them.  Hit 'em where it hurts -- right in the nuts.  More assassinations, more killings.  Right, Al?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These State Department jerks, Bill, don't understand; you got to electrify people with bold moves.  Bold moves make history, like Teddy Roosevelt -- "T.R." -- rushing up San Juan Hill.  Small event but dramatic.  People took notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll take notice all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact is if we sneak out of this war, there'll be another one a mile down the road. (pause) We bite the bullet here.  In Cambodia.  We blow the hell out of these people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should we tell the press?

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY
dialogues.text: FOOTAGE - 9. Bombs dropping over Cambodia. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 10. Combined U.S. and SOUTH VIETNAMESE TROOPS invade CAMBODIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, American and South Vietnamese units will attack the headquarters for the entire Communist military operation in South Vietnam.  This is not an invasion of Cambodia.  We take this action not for the purpose of expanding the war into Cambodia, but for the purpose of ending the war in Vietnam ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 11. The Administration Building at BERKELEY is burning.  POLICE in riot gear move in.  A BATTLE between STUDENTS and POLICE is taking place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the country, several hundred universities are in turmoil as students battle police in protest against the invasion of Cambodia ...

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A phalanx of NATIONAL GUARDSMEN advances.  They look very young and scared.  A CROWD of STUDENTS taunts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a speech) When I think of those kids out there, kids who are just doing their duty ...

dialogues.speaker: IN. THE WHITE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The end of a ceremony for a released VIETNAM POW.  NIXON, with JULIE, stands before emotional WIVES, DEFENSE DEPARTMENT EMPLOYEES, and UNIFORMED OFFICERS.  The POW si in a wheelchair at NIXON'S elbow, emaciated, the blue ribbon of the Congressional Medal of Honor around his nec PAT is also there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues) I'm sure they're scared.  I was when I was there.  But when it really comes down to it ... (turns to the POW) ... you have to look up to these men.  They're the greatest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.  The POW manages a smile. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - An ugly stand-off.  The STUDENTS confront the GUARDSMEN, jeering.  The GUARDSMEN lower the bayonets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) One-two-three-four.  We don't want your fucking war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone throws a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues) You see these bums, you know, blowing up the campuses, burning books and so forth.  They call themselves "flower children."  Well, I call them spoiled rotten.  And I tell you what would cure them -- a good old-fashioned trip to my Ohio father's woodshed.  That's what these bums need!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - More STUDENTS are throwing rocks.  The GUARDSMEN are momentarily panicked, confused. Then, suddenly: they open fire.  A melee.  Screaming.  STUDENTS running. Then: half a dozen BODIES lie on the ground.  A young WOM crouches over a BODY, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, less than twenty-four hours after President Nixon called them "bums," four students were shot dead at Kent State University in Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits at the head of an outdoor dinner table with HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN, ZIEGLER, KISSINGER.  They are being served steaks by MANOLO, Nixon's Cuban valet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enraged student groups across the country are calling for a general strike tomorrow to shut down the entire university system until the Vietnam War is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.  Two boys.  Two girls.  And eight wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the fathers was on the TV saying, "My child was not a bum."  And it's playing like gangbusters.  Hell, Hoover told me one of the girls was a nymph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, the press doesn't care about the facts.  Cronkite's sticking it to me.  It's their first big hit on Richard Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The governor says they were rioting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The governor's full of shit.  Most of them were changing classes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose you would've just let them take over.  These aren't fraternity pranks, John.  It's anarchy.  A revolution!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I'd go that far, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the war worth it?  Is it worth a one-term presidency?  Because I think right now that's what we're looking at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not go down as the first American president to lose a war!  Going into Cambodia, bombing Hanoi, bombing Laos -- it buys us time so we can get out and give the South Vietnamese a fighting chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly, sir.  That is your historical contribution: to lead boldly in an era of limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinks) No one understands! -- even my own men.  What do you think the Communists respond to?  Honesty, liberal guilt, soul-wringing crap, fathers on TV crying?  Hell no!  I understand the Communist mind, I've studied it for thirty years.  They grasp "realpolitik" better than any of us, right, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta make 'em think we're just as tough as they are -- that Nixon's a mad bomber, he might do anything!  I played a lot of poker in World War II (Haldeman and Ehrlichman know the story), and I won big, and let me tell you this -- unpredictability is our best asset.  That redneck Johnson left me with a shitty hand and I'm bluffing.  I've got to play the hawk in Vietnam and the dove in China.  And if we keep our heads, we can win this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Win Vietnam, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  But what we can do with Vietnam, Ron, is drive a stake through the heart of the Communist alliance!  Henry's already getting strong signals from the Chinese.  They hate the Viets more than the Russians, and they're worried about a unified Vietnam.  The Russians hate the Chinese and are supporting the Viets, you understand?  If we stick it out in Vietnam ... we'll end up negotiating separately with both the Chinese and the Soviets.  And we'll get better deals than we ever dreamed of from both ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's triangular diplomacy, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly, yes, Mr. President.  That is my contention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what geopolitics is about -- the whole world linked by self interest ... You tell me, Ron, how the hell I can explain that on television to a bunch of simple-minded reporters and weeping fucking mothers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what am I telling the press about Kent State?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em what you like; they'll never understand it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me ... Are you talking about recognizing China, Mr. President?  That would cost us our strongest support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... I can do this because I've spent my whole career building anti Communist credentials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Johnson or Kennedy tried it, they'd have crucified them, and rightfully so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's damned risky, Mr. President.  Why don't we wait till the second term?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeats) This will get me a second term.  Damn it, without risk, there's no heroism.  There's no history.  I, Nixon, was born to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, this cannot be breathed!  Especially to our secretary of state -- that cretin Rogers ... The Chinese would never trust us again.  The only way, I emphasize only way, to pull this off is in secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cackles) This is a major coup, gentlemen -- our own State Department doesn't even know.  And if it leaks out of here tonight ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  He eyes them.  Discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, one way or the other, Kent State is not good.  We have to get out in front of this thing.  The PR is going to murder us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.  Follow the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These kids are being manipulated by the Communists.  Like Chambers and Hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoking his pipe) This isn't '48, Dick.  They'll never buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) How do you know that, John?  Did we try?  Are we just giving up like the rest of 'em?  What's Hoover found, for God's sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he called the other day, sir.  He asked for President Harding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter around the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an idiot ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, sir, he's gotta go ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't touch Hoover --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the gloves were off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as long as he's got secret files on everybody.  I don't want 'em used against us. (frustrated) What about the CIA?  Helms's done nothing for us.  I want to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Hiss, Mr. President, you had the microfilm, you had the lie.  With the students, we got no proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers were provoked.  The students started it, for Christ's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there's dead American kids here.  Let's say we don't apologize for Kent State, but maybe we could have a national prayer day ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... never complain, never explain, John ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells) I tell you, the soldiers were provoked.  Now stop this pussyfooting around. (irritated) Dead kids!  How the hell did we ever give the Democrats a weapon like this? (then) I mean, if Cambodia doesn't work, we'll bomb Hanoi if we have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at him.  He is resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right!  And if necessary, I'll drop the big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to entertain the possibility ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks down at his steak.  It is oozing blood.  Too much blood -- something is very wrong.  He shoots back, momentarily terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it!  Who the hell cooked this steak? (yells) Manolo, there's blood all over my plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON throws down his knife and fork and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is on the bow, alone, watching the city slip by.  MITCHELL slides up beside him, offering him a freshened drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother Harold was about the same age as those kids, John.  Tuberculosis got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault.  The soldiers were just kids, too.  They panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were throwing rocks, John, just rocks.  They don't think I feel ... but I feel too much sometimes.  I just can't let a whole policy get dominated by our sentimentality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing the right thing, Dick ... don't let 'em shake you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It broke my heart when Harold died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks out at the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's when it starts.  When you're a kid.  The laughs and snubs and slights you get because you're poor or Irish or Jewish or just ugly.  But if you're intelligent, and your anger is deep enough and strong enough, you learn you can change these attitudes by excellence, gut performance, while those who have everything are sitting on their fat butts ... (then) But then when you get to the top, you find you can't stop playing the game the way you've always played it because it's a part of you like an arm or a leg.  So you're lean and mean and you continue to walk the edge of the precipice, because over the years you've become fascinated by how close you can get without falling ... I wonder, John, I wonder ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell puts his hand on Dick's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off that.  That leads nowhere.  You should offer condolences to the families of those kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'd like to offer condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs off Mitchell's hand and walks down the deck int the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Nixon can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the WHITE HOUSE, NIXON looks out at ANGRY DEMONSTRATORS giving him the finger, shaking placards -- "IMPEACH NIXON" (spelled with a swastika), "PEACE NOW."  With him are HALDEMAN and EHRLICHMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with clipboard) ... and we've got the economic guys at five.  The Dow lost another 16 points.  They're going to want a decision on the budget.  Sir?  ... Are we holding the line on a balanced budget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... a little deficit won't hurt.  Jesus, they're serious.  Why're we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Run 'em over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The presidential limousine has a difficult time negotiati its way through the BLOCKADING BUSES.  A MAN with a NIXON mask runs up to the window and peers in, before being peeled off by SECRET SERVICE.  It is an ugly, violent scene, but Nixon seems to delight in the threat of action He's in an upbeat mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that little fucker!  Great tackle!  Reminds me of my days at Whittier.  Most of these kids are useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably flunking, nothing to do except come down here and meet girls.  Henry's out there with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a poison in the upper classes, Bob.  They've had it too soft.  Too many cars, too many color TVs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget the South, sir, the West.  Filled with the good football colleges, straight kids.  There's more of 'em with you than against you.  Not like these mudmutts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the parents' fault really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not forget they're just kids, they don't vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the fall of the Roman Empire, are you blind?  And we're putting fig leaves on the statues ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh is going to win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that fucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glum moment.  Haldeman stares at him.  A PROTESTOR wave a Vietcong flag in Nixon's face.  He gets pulled off the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhilarated) But, hell, this is nothing compared to Venezuela.  When I was Vice President, Ike sent me down there like a blocking back.  They threw rocks, broke out our windows, almost overturned the car.  Read Six Crises, Bob.  Boy, Pat was brave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've got to get our vice president off the golf course and back there on the college circuit.  That's top priority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the dumps, sir.  Agnew.  Every time you have him attack the press, they give it back to him in spades.  He's become the most hated man in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Yeah, good old Spiro.  Well, better him than me.  What the hell is he but an insurance policy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta keep reminding the media pricks, if Nixon goes they end up with Agnew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's begging for a meeting, chief.  He wants to go overseas for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no place where they speak English.  That way he can always say he was misquoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon emits a high, manic laugh. The PROTESTORS are frustrated as the limousine breaks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SEAL of the CIA: "You shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free."  We CRANE BACK, revealing tha the seal is on the floor of the LOBBY as NIXON strides in with his ENTOURAGE. LT. GENERAL ROBERT CUSHMAN hurries out, ruffled, to meet NIXON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I don't know what to say.  As soon as we learned from the Secret Service you were en route, the Director was notified.  He should be here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, he's rushing back from his tennis game, sir ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) So ... let's go ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking with Nixon) He told me to take you to his conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  His office. (aside) I want a very private conversation.  I don't want to be bugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then his office will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk past ANALYSTS laboring in isolation behind Plexiglass walls; the hum of computers, a dark austerity the place.  They all glance up as NIXON strides past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the job coming, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, sir, it stinks.  I have no access.  I'm lucky Helms lets me have a staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ominous) We'll see about that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing change) He's nervous, sir.  He's heard you're looking for a new director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he certainly isn't acting like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Helms.  He's "sang froid," a world-class poker player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Yeah?  Well, I own the fucking casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DUTY OFFICER opens the door of the director's office wi a flourish.  NIXON catches RICHARD HELMS throwing his trench coat and tennis racket on a chair, obviously hurrying in from a secret door.  Helms spots Nixon, exten his hand with a reptilian smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honored, Dick, that you've come all this way out here to Virginia to visit us at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends call me "Mister President."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so shall I. (to Cushman) Arrange some coffee, would you General Cushman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cushman stares back a beat, bitterly.  Nixon signals to Haldeman and Ehrlichman that he, too, wants to be alone.  The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Cushman is a lieutenant general in the Marine Corps, the Deputy Director of the CIA ... and this is what you use him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't choose him as my deputy, Mr. President.  You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon paces the office, which is festooned with photos, awards and an abundance of flowers, particularly orchids. A collector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live pretty well out here.  Now I understand why you want to keep your budget classified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helms sits on a settee, a hard-to-read man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose, "Mister President," you're unhappy that we have not implemented your Domestic Intelligence plan, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
