dialogues.text: You're correct.  I'm concerned these students are being funded by foreign interests, whether they know it or not.  The FBI is worthless in this area.  I want your full concentration on this matter ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we've tried, but so far we've come up with nothing that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stern) Then find something.  And I want these leaks stopped.  Jack fucking Anderson, the New York Times, the State Department -- I want to know who's talking to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you realize this is a very tricky area, Mr. President, given our charter and the congressional oversight committees ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw congressional oversight.  I know damn well, going back to the '50's, this agency reports what it wants, and buries what it doesn't want Congress to know.  Pay close attention to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon fixes him with his stare.  Helms clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something else that's bothering you, Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... It involves some old and forgotten papers.  Things I signed as Vice President.  I want the originals in my office and I don't want copies anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now knowing Nixon's cards, Helms relaxes -- about an inch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're referring, of course, to chairing the Special Operations Group as Vice President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helms wanders over to his prize orchids, fingers them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know ... that was unique.  Not an operation as much as ... an organic phenomenon.  It grew, it changed shape, it developed ... insatiable, devouring appetites. (then) It's not uncommon in such cases that things are not committed to paper.  That could be very ... embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon is embarrassed, and does not like it.  Suddenly, th Beast is in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reminding him) I, for one, saw to it that my name was never connected to any of those operations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Nixon, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fishing) Diem?  Trujillo?  Lumumba?  Guatemala?  Cuba? ... It's a shame you didn't take similar precautions, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very uncomfortable) I'm interested in the documents that put your people together with ... the others.  All of them ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  This is the fastball.  Helms pours himself a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Kennedy threatened to smash the CIA into a thousand pieces.  You could do the same ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Jack Kennedy.  Your agency is secure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stirs the coffee) Not if I give you all the cards ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised the American people peace with honor in Southeast Asia.  That could take time -- two, maybe three years ... In the meantime, your agency will continue at current levels of funding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sips his coffee) Current levels may not be sufficient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President would support a reasonable request for an increase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helms smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And me? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firing you, Mr. Helms, wouldn't do any good.  Of course you'll continue as DCI.  You're doing a magnificent job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of course I accept.  I'm flattered.  And I want you to know, I work for only one president at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  And you will give General Cushman full access.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly accepts that) It will take a little time, but I'll order a search for your papers.  Though it does raise a disturbing issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Castro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have recent intelligence that a Soviet nuclear submarine has docked at Cienfuegos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll lodge a formal protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we can treat this as a formality.  Mr. Kennedy made a verbal promise to the Russians not to invade Cuba.  But you authorized Dr. Kissinger to put this in writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon is taken aback by Helms's inside knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you tapping Kissinger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job, unpleasant sometimes, is to know what others don't want me to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Not if you have spies in the White House, it isn't your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not my practice to spy on the president.  Doctor Kissinger manages to convey his innermost secrets to the world at large on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absorbs this) Mr. Helms, we've lived with Communism in Cuba for ten years ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But it has never been the policy of this government to accept that.  And it is certainly not CIA policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CIA policy?  The CIA has no policy, Mr. Helms.  Except what I dictate to you ... (beat, they stare at each other) I try to adjust to the world as it is today, not as you or I wanted it to be ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you and Kissinger are negotiating with the Chinese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Nixon stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an extremely dangerous direction, Mr. President.  Terrible consequences can result from such enormous errors in judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But ... if we were able to separate China from Russia once and for all, we can -- we could create a balance of power that would secure the peace into the next century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By offering Cuba to the Russians as a consolation prize?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuba would be a small price to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So President Kennedy thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disturbing image suddenly appears in Nixon's mind -- KENNEDY with his head blown off in Dallas.  Followed by a IMAGE of his own death.  In a coffin. The smell of the orchids in the room is overwhelming.  Nixon feels himself dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought Jack was ready for the presidency.  But I would never, never consider ... (then) His death was awful, an awful thing for this country. (then) Do you ever think of death, Mr. Helms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers are continual reminders of our mortality.  Do you appreciate flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  They make me sick.  They smell like death ... I had two brothers die young.  But let me tell you, there are worse things than death.  There is such a thing as evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be familiar with my favorite poem by Yeats?  "The Second Coming"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Irishman.  Very moving.  "Turning and turning in the widening gyre / The falcon cannot hear the falconer / Things fall apart, the center cannot hold / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world / And everywhere the ceremony of innocence is drowned / The best lack all conviction, while the worst are full of passionate intensity" ... But it ends so beautifully ominous -- "What rough beast, its hours come round at last / Slouches toward Bethlehem to be born?" ... Yes, this country stands at such a juncture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Nixon, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON has just returned from a dinner party, this tuxedo coming off, on the phone, a Scotch in hand, in high spirits.  A series of JUMP CUTS of his phone self as follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was sudden death, Trini, but I think I kicked Helms's ass. (laughs) Yeah, and Kissinger's running around like a scared chicken right now; he doesn't know who's gonna grab his power.  Yeah ... you should see him.  I call Haig, Kissinger shits!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the look on Hoover's face?  He was redder than a beet.  That little closet fairy's got no choice.  He hates McGovern and Kennedy so much, he's got to love me.  And Lyndon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT enters, in a nightdress, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked old, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hardly noticing) I asked him, "Lyndon, what would you do, on a scale of one to ten?"  And he said, "Bomb the shit out of Hanoi, boy!  Bomb them where they live." ... John, do you think I was too soft on TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I want to get on this energy thing tomorrow -- we really have to rethink our needs to the end of the century.  Let's do it at 1:00.  And don't forget the budget boys.  I'm gonna carve the shit out of 'em. (beat) Well, no, clear the afternoon and tell Trini I'll be in Key Biscayne by 4:00 ... No, alone ... Pat's staying here with the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat approaches him, nuzzles him.  She seems a little strange, tipsy ... but sexy in her nightdress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pat) Uh, you should check with Bob ... (to Bob) Listen, Bob, I'll call you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Buddy.  What are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspecting drink on her breath) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we go down to Key Biscayne together?  Just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because ... I have to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking tonight -- do you remember, Dick?  Do you remember when you used to drive me on dates with the other boys?  You didn't want to let me out of your sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's been a long time ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A signal has been given.  Nixon recoils, embarrassed.  A slight sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need that, Buddy.  I'm not Jack Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rebuffed, distant) No, you're not.  So stop comparing yourself to him.  You have no reason to ... You have everything you ever wanted.  You've earned it.  Why can't you just enjoy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  I do.  In my own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you scared of, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not scared, Buddy. (a pause) You don't understand.  They're playing for keeps, Buddy.  The press, the kids, the liberals -- they're out there, trying to figure out how to tear me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all your enemies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You personally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  This is about me.  Why can't you understand that, you of all people?  It's not the war -- it's Nixon!  They want to destroy Nixon!  And if I expose myself even the slightest bit they'll tear my insides out.  Do you want that?  Do you want to see that, Buddy?  It's not pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think that's what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been drinking.  What the hell are you saying?  Jesus, you sound like them now! ... (a beat, quietly) I've gotta keep fighting, Buddy, for the country.  These people running things, the elite ... they're soft, chickenshit faggots!  They don't have the long-term vision anymore.  They just want to cover their asses or meet girls or tear each other down.  Oh, God, this country's in deep trouble, Buddy ... and I have to see this through.  Mother would've wanted no less of me ... I'm sorry, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat stands, about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wish ... you knew how much I love you, that's all.  It took me a long time to fall in love with you, Dick.  But I did it.  And it doesn't make you happy.  You want them to love you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat waves outward, indicating the world, the public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjects) No, I don't.  I'm not Jack ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they never will, Dick.  No matter how many elections you win, they never will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.  He is left in the middle of the room.  He shuffles to the phone, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manolo!  Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights come on, revealing MANOLO SANCHEZ, the valet, the doorway, wearing a bathrobe and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was asleep, Mr. President.  What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ... uh ... you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manolo moves to a cabinet on the far side of the pantry.  Takes out a bottle of Chivas, puts ice into a tumbler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you miss Cuba, Manolo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We let you down, didn't we.  Your people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Mr. Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think he was a hero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manolo pours Nixon a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) He was a politician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows the drink) Did you cry when he died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (then) He made me see the stars ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks outside, to himself) How did he do that? (then) All those kids ... Why do they hate me so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON gets out of the front of the presidential LIMOUSINE MANOLO follows. Nixon looks up: a surreal scene.  The Lincoln Memorial ha been turned into a pagan temple.  FIRES burn on the broad marble steps, half-naked KIDS sleep on filthy blankets below the immense columns.  Hendrix plays faintly on a portable radio.  Nixon starts up the steps, picking his w among the sleeping forms. He passes a GIRL, tripping, eyes closed, twirling a long scarf over her head.  He stares at her, steps on a sleepi bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, man.  That's my fuckin' leg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY's jaw drops.  Nixon towers over him.  An apparition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just go back to sleep now, young fella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubs his eyes) Whoa, this is some nasty shit ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon reaches the top of the monument.  Taped to one of t pillars is a poster.  Nixon scowling, and the motto "Woul You Buy A Used Car From This Man?" Nixon peers at it, moves inside.  He looks up at LINCOLN the eerie firelight.  Banners with peace signs have been draped over his shoulders, bunches of flowers between his fingers. HALF A DOZEN STUDENTS are talking among themselves.  They see Nixon, stop.  Stunned.  Nixon strides toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Dick Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shittin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Syracuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Orangemen!  Now there's a football program.  Jim Brown.  And that other tailback ... The one with the blood disease ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right.  I used to play a little ball myself at Whittier. (laughs nervously) Of course, they used me as a tackling dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A self-possessed YOUNG WOMAN abruptly interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't come here to talk about football.  We came here to end the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chastened) Yes, I understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  Nobody responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably most of you think I'm a real SOB.  I know that.  But I understand how you feel, I really do.  I want peace, too, but peace with honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have peace without a price.  Sometimes you have to be willing to fight for peace.  And sometimes to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to the GIs who are going to die tomorrow in Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you have to understand, Mr. Nixon, is that we are willing to die for what we believe in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at Lincoln) That man up there lived in similar times.  He had chaos and civil war and hatred between the races ... Sometimes I go to the Lincoln Room at the White House and just pray.  You know, the liberals act like idealism belongs to them, but it's not true.  My family went Republican because Lincoln freed the slaves.  My grandmother was an abolitionist.  It was Quakers who founded Whittier, my hometown, to abolish slavery.  They were conservative Bible folk, but they had a powerful sense of right and wrong ... Forty years ago I was looking, as you are now, for answers. (then) But you know, ending the war and cleaning up the air and the cities, feeding the poor -- my mother used to feed hobos stopping over at our house  - none of it is going to satisfy the spiritual hunger we all have, finding a meaning to this life ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALDEMAN arrives with SEVERAL SECRET SERVICE AGENTS, looking very worried.  The crowd around Nixon has grown much larger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Bob, we're just rapping, my friends and I.  We actually agree on a lot of things ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't!  You're full of shit!  You say you want to end the war, so why don't you?  My brother died over there last November.  Why?  What good was his death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know.  I've seen a lot of kids die, too, in World War II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man -- Vietnam ain't Germany.  It doesn't threaten us.  It's a civil war between the Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But change always comes slowly.  I've withdrawn more than half the troops.  I'm trying to cut the military budget for the first time in thirty years.  I want an all-volunteer army.  But it's also a question of American credibility, our position in the world ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want the war.  We don't want the war.  The Vietnamese don't want the war.  So why does it go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon hesitates, out of answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone wants it ... (a realization) You can't stop it, can you?  Even if you wanted to.  Because it's not you.  It's the system.  And the system won't let you stop it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot more at stake here than what you want.  Or even what I want ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the point?  What's the point of being president?  You're powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl transfixes him with her eyes.  Nixon feels it.  The nausea of the Beast makes him reel.  The students pre in on him from all sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stumbling) No, no.  I'm not powerless.  Because ... because I understand the system.  I believe I can control it.  Maybe not control it totally.  But ... tame it enough to make it do some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds like you're talking about a wild animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.  Nixon looks at her. Haldeman and the SECRET SERVICE MEN fill the succeeding beat of silence by moving Nixon off.  He allows himself t be herded, waving absently to the protestors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really must go, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to all) Don't forget, the most important thing in your life is your relationship with your Maker ... (over his shoulder to all) Don't forget to be on God's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't go down well with the protestors. ("Bullshit!") As Nixon is led down the steps to the limousine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got it, Bob.  A nineteen-year-old college kid ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She understood something it's taken me twenty-five fucking years in politics to understand.  The CIA, the Mafia, the Wall Street bastards ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing into the limo, mutters) ... "The Beast."  A nineteen-year-old kid.  She understands the nature of "the Beast."  She called it a wild animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes.  The LIMOUSINE is whisked away under searchlights and heavy security.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - The White House is still ringed.  ARMED TROOPS patrol Pennsylvania Avenue.  The BUSES are drawn up.  SMOKE is in the air.  The SOUNDS of cherry bom going off.  Signs that read: "End the war!  Throw the fascists out!  Dick Nixon before he dicks you!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the barricades, a fairyland.  A white lattice gaze draped with flowers.  TRICIA's wedding is in preparation. GROUNDSKEEPERS and various PERSONNEL lay out the carpet t the alter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J. EDGAR HOOVER joins NIXON, pulling on his wedding tuxed at a window, looking out at the PROTESTORS.  Intermittently, Hoover helps him with his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing) There must be a quarter-million out there, Edgar.  They've been at it now for a year.  Young kids just like Tricia.  I don't know.  Do you think they have a point, Edgar?  Maybe this whole damned system of government is ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspecting softness) Remember what Lenin said in 1917, Mr. President: "The power was lying in the streets just waiting for someone to pick it up."  The Communists have never been closer.  Now is the time to go back to the old themes, the ones that made you president.  Let the Communists know you're onto them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) The little bastards think they can ruin Tricia's wedding day by dancing naked in the Reflecting Pond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to 'em, don't quit.  Remember - Kennedy, Bobby, and King were against the war.  Where are they now?  Don't give 'em a goddamn inch on the war.  President Johnson bombed Laos for years and nobody knew or said a thing.  How the hell the Times ever got ahold of this Ellsberg stuff is a disgrace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't keep a goddamn secret in this government, Edgar.  They're stealing papers right out of his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson had the same damned problem till he bugged his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) We took his system out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a mistake.  The White House was full of Kennedy people then.  It still is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think is behind it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you have CIA people all over the place.  Helms has seen to that. (beat, Nixon remains poker faced) Then there's Kissinger's staff.  Kissinger himself, I believe, maybe the leaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) Kissinger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's obsessed with his own image.  He wants his Nobel Peace Prize a little too much.  As the late "Doctor" King proved -- even an ape can win a prize with good press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'd like to book him into a psychiatrist's office.  He comes in here ranting and raving, dumping his crap all over the place ... Could you prove it, Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always get my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you do. (then) I'd be bugging myself, Edgar ... Who'd get the tapes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.  Your property.  It would prove your case.  Why do you think Kissinger's taping your calls?  For history.  His word against yours -- and right now he's got the records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon is stung by the comparison, fussing with his bow ti Hoover helps him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This damned tie ... Will you help me, Edgar? (then) Churchill used to say to me, "If you want your own history written properly, you must write it yourself." (starts out) All right, Edgar, but just don't let it come back to haunt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a reminder) It won't.  As long as I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon absentmindedly shows Hoover through a small door in his BATHROOM ... There is an awkward pause, as both men a too proud to pretend they are cramped in this place together.  Hoover clears his throat and exits the regular door.  As we hear the Love Theme from "Doctor Zhivago":

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White House GUARDS wear German comic opera uniforms including tall cylindrical hats with beaks.  We see champagne, white lace, the MUSICIANS wearing morning coat HOOVER and TOLSON are together, very happy.  To the sound of the wedding MUSIC, NIXON takes a turn with his daughte TRICIA, in gown.  He has never seemed happier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very proud of you today, princess.  Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When one of the GROOMSMEN cuts in, Nixon asks several OTHERS to dance.  He retreats to JULIE's side.  Julie say something sweet but unheard to him. PAT is at a window, upset, looking out at the PROTESTORS Julie comes over to get her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Mother, join the ... (sees her look) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just not going to buckle to these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat puts on her party face and rejoins the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CABINET MEMBERS chat, lean back in their chairs, smoking, as NIXON suddenly erupts into the room, a focused fury on his face.  He sits, slams the New York Times down.  CLOSE we can make out the words "Pentagon Papers."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, we've had our last damn leak!  This is no way to run a goddamn government.  We're going to prosecute the hell out of Ellsberg and anyone else who wants to leak.  And that means any one of you who crosses the line, I'm personally going after ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING among the faces -- KISSINGER predominant.  Nixon glances in his direction, pause on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The permissiveness of this era is over.  The belts are coming off and people are gonna be taken to the woodshed.  This government cannot survive with a counter-government inside it.  I know how traitors operate -- I've dealt with them all my life.  This bullshit to the effect -- some stenographer did it, some stenographer -- that's never the case.  It's never the little people -- little people do not leak.  It's always the sonofabitch like Ellsberg who leaks!  The Harvard Hebrew boys with the private agendas who wanna be heroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon grabs the paper, shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellsberg did this "for the good of the country."  I suppose you've never heard that one before.  Alger Hiss and the Rosenbergs said the same damn crap, and you know what happened to them -- ol' Sparky got them.  They've always underestimated Nixon, the intellectuals.  Well, we're gonna let them know we can fight just as dirty.  This is sudden death, gentlemen.  We're gonna get 'em on the ground, stick in our spikes and twist, show 'em no mercy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks around the room.  The Cabinet members are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This administration is a goddamn disaster.  We got bums out there at the gates.  We've got thirty-eight of forty pieces of our domestic legislation defeated in Congress.  Unless we turn things around, we'll all be looking for jobs next year. (then) Starting today, nobody in this room talks to the press without clearing it first with Haldeman.  That means a complete freeze on the New York Times, CBS, Jack fucking Anderson, and the Washington Post!  From now on, Haldeman is the Lord High Executioner.  So don't you come whining to me when he tells you to do something, 'cause that's me talking.  And if you come to me, I'll be tougher than he is.  Anybody tries to screw us, his head comes off.  Do you understand?  Good day, gentlemen ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, leaving them stunned and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess that's it for today's meeting ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chicken's head flies off.  The CUBAN CROWD is going cra as a FIGHTING COCK is moving in for the kill.  The ring i surrounded by impromptu bleachers, the walls lined with metal cages filled with chickens.  The slaughterhouse is adjacent. HOWARD HUNT stands at the edge of the crowd, holding a greasy wrapper of churos, as the fight ends. Cheers and groans.  Fistfuls of money are exchanged. FRANK STURGIS turns from the ring, makes his way to Hunt, hands him a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Injections.  Even this noble sport's been fixed. (pockets the twenty) Seen the guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sturgis snags a piece of churo, swallows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you got a customer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops) You're fucking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna be plumbers, Frank.  We're gonna plug a leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who we working for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy named Gordon Liddy.  Thinks he's Martin Borman.  You wanna meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions. GORDON LIDDY comes out of the edges of the crowd, shakes hands with Sturgis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Liddy ... Frank Sturgis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn the handshake into a parallel of the cock fight iron grips subtly crush each other's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after they break) Y'ever hold your hand over a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liddy pulls out a Zippo lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, Gordon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt motions him off.  As Liddy drifts off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't tell him to do anything you don't really want him to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, does Tricky Dick know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tell him if you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HANDLERS throw TWO NEW FIGHTING COCKS into the ring.  They start to rip at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing on his churo) The claws are out, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As seen before: a GLASS shatters, a CROWBAR jacks open th door marked: "Dr. Lewis J. Fielding, Psychiatrist."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History will never be the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabinets full of pills are overturned.  The disguised HUN and LIDDY, with the three CUBANS, go to work.  A FILE FOLDER is ripped from a cabinet.  In the flashlight beam the file reads "Daniel Ellsberg."  A VOICE calls out: "Howard, I got it!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've taken a step into the future.  We've changed the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "America the Beautiful" MUSIC takes us into:

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: NIXON beams, standing under a huge red flag bearing the hammer and sickle.  The "America" theme is being played o a traditional Chinese instrument as CHINESE PHOTOGRAPHERS are allowed to take stiff portraits.  The MEN chit-chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say you look very good, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks can be deceiving ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know you've taken a great risk in inviting us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAO stares at Nixon and replies in Chinese, which the INTERPRETER repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half smiles) I took no risk.  I'm too old to be afraid of what anyone thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon forces a rigid smile as they move to the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAO and NIXON are seated in armchairs opposite each other KISSINGER and CHOU EN-LAI to either side of Mao.  An INTERPRETER between.  In media res:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever trust them.  They never tell the truth or honor their commitments.  Vietnamese are like Russians.  Both are dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, there is an old saying: The enemy of my enemy is my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) That has the added virtue of being true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mao doesn't seem to be taking any of this too seriously; fact, he seems a little medicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Mr. Chairman, at Harvard I used your writings in my class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a waste of time.  My writings mean absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your writings have changed the world, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fung pi! (Bullshit!)  I've only managed to change a few things around the city of Beijing. (then: to Kissinger) I want to know your secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secret, Mr. Chairman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How a fat man gets so many girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mao howls at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power, Mr. Chairman, is the ultimate aphrodisiac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to Nixon) You know, I voted for you in your last election.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self-effacing) I was the lesser of two evils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.  Mao levels a gaze at him, deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too modest, Nixon.  You're as evil as I am.  We're both from poor families.  But others pay to feed the hunger in us.  In my case, millions of reactionaries.  In your case, millions of Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Civil war is always the cruelest kind of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real war is in us. (then) History is a symptom of our disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a surprise Christmas bombing of Hanoi, President Nixon delivered more tonnage than was used at Dresden in World War II ... It is, without a doubt, the most brutal bombing in American history.

dialogues.speaker: CROSSCUT
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE - 1. HANOI - the devastation of the city.  It's on fire.  Bodies are being carried from a collapsed HOSPITAL. 2. The USA - in contrast, shots in th media of Christmas trees (Rockefeller Center, etc.); families shopping; a children's choir singing "Gloria in Excelsis Deo."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This Christmas bombing has shaken up the Paris peace talks and created a huge amount of criticism across the globe.  Newspapers are calling it a "Stone Age tactic," and Nixon a "maddened tyrant" ... Nixon's only response: "When the Vietnamese take the peace talks seriously, I'll stop."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOCK FOOTAGE - moving through a bank of clouds toward th sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is looking out the window, PAT next to him.  HALDEM and EHRLICHMAN are out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny for your thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that adjusted for inflation? (she laughs) Think of the life Mao's led.  In '52 I called him a monster.  Now he could be our most important ally. (then) Only Nixon could've done that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a long way from Whittier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  He shares her look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat puts her hand on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) How am I going to break this to Bob Hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KISSINGER walks into the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got the Russians where we want them!  They're calling us.  We will have a SALT treaty with them this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time for the election?  Brezhnev's tough.  He knows McGovern's right on our ass ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have a choice!  He has to shift missiles from Europe to the Chinese border.  With one stroke, the balance of power moves completely in our favor.  This is a coup, Mr. President!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, Henry?  Nobel Peace Prize, maybe ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees the look on Nixon's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for the Pentagon it isn't.  I'm kissing Mao's ass.  And the press is gonna find some way to shaft Nixon on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the press that matters.  Nixon's wife is proud of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his staff.  Come on, the copy they were filing from China was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait till the Mai-tais wear off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country's loving it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hard-core four million "Nixon nuts" aren't gonna go for it ... They'll say I sold out to the Communists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll pick up the middle on this one  - the Jews and Negros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jews and Negros don't win elections, Henry.  Better to hang them around the Democrats' necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jews aren't the middle, Henry.  They're the far left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking too much about black Africa, Henry.  It's killing us with the rednecks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blacks are lost, the "schwartzes" are gone ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it lose us the right-wing vote ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence as the sour notes depress everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling the deflation) Hey, I sound like my father now.  Let's have a drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat smiles.  ZIEGLER pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the press guys asked if you could come back for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go back, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone glares at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they want you, Mr. President.  I really think it would be a good move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I go now to discover the exact length, width and depth of the shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON closes the door behind him, turns. DOZENS of REPORTERS stand, burst into applause. He is momentarily stunned, then he moves down the aisle.  Shaking hands.  The reporters continue applauding.  Nixon for once, is deeply moved.  On the sound of applause, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J. Edgar Hoover is dead at the age of seventy-seven.  The legendary crime buster served his country as Director of the FBI for almost half a century, from 1924 to 1972.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous BRAHMA BULL, red-eyed, snorting, thrashes viciously against the reinforced walls of its pen.  NIXON and JACK JONES watch as SECRET SERVICE hover nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two kinds of bulls, Dick.  Your good bull and your bad bull.  This here's a bad bull.  You piss him off, he'll kill everything in his path.  Only way to stop him is to shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WRANGLER climbs carefully into the chute.  The Brahma lunges for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, you be damned careful with that beast.  His nuts are worth a helluva lot more'n yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads Nixon down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cagey) So, what's this about, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me or Wallace, Jack.  Wallace's third party is only going to help McGovern.  I need your support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you sure been chock full of surprises so far, "Mister President."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON and HALDEMAN are standing by the hearth.  The years have gone by but, in different clothing and hairstyles, i is much the same group of a DOZEN BUSINESSMEN gathered around, drinking Jack Daniels and smoking cigars.  Among them we recognize the CUBAN and MITCH.  It's heated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like to me we're gonna lose the war for the first goddamned time and, Dick, goddamn it, you're going along with it, buying into this Kissinger bullshit -- "detente" with the Communists.  "Detente" -- it sounds like two fags dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, we're not living in the same country you and I knew in '46.  Our people are just not gonna sacrifice in major numbers for war.  We can't even get 'em to accept cuts in their gas tanks.  Hell, the Arabs and the Japanese are bleeding the shit out of our gold ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whose fault is that?  If we'd won in Vietnam ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nobody's fault, Jack.  It's change -- which is a fact of history.  Even that old cocksucker Hoover's dead.  Things change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncomfortable silence.  A servant brings coffee to Nixon, but Haldeman cuts him off.  No one gets close to h guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ... how's the food over there in China, Mr. Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free, if you're the president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do about this Allende fellow nationalizing our businesses in Chile?  You gonna send Kissinger down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna get rid of him -- Allende, I mean -- just as fast as we can.  He's on the top of the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Kissinger along with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger's misunderstood.  He pretends to be a liberal for his Establishment friends, but he's even tougher than I am ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Kissinger stays.  Just like Castro, Mr. Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he stays ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncomfortable silence.  Jones walks closer to Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desi's got a point.  What the hell are we gonna do about the Communists right here in our backyard?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I got federal price controls on my oil.  The ragheads are beating the shit out of me.  And I got your EPA environment agency with its thumb so far up my ass it's scratching my ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I think it's about time for us to be getting to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him finish, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And now I have a federal judge ordering me to bus my kids halfway 'cross town to go to school with some nigger kids.  I think, Mr. President, you're forgetting who put you where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American people put me where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jones smirks.  They all smirk.  A dreadful moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Well, that can be changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead silence.  Nixon moves closer to Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I've learned that politics is the art of compromise.  I learned it the hard way.  I don't know if you have.  But I tell you what, Jack ... If you don't like it, there's an election in November.  You can take your money out into the open, give it to Wallace ... How about it, Jack?  Are you willing to do that?  Give this country over to some poet-pansy socialist like George McGovern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon is right in Jones's face now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you're uncomfortable with the EPA up your ass, try the IRS ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, goddamn.  Are you threatening me, Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Presidents don't threaten.  They don't have to. (then) Good day, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks out with Haldeman, there is a stone silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the PRESIDENTIAL CAR pulls away in a three-car entourage, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... With George Wallace out of the race, paralyzed by an assassin's bullet, Richard Nixon has crushed George McGovern in the 1972 presidential election.  It is the second biggest landslide in American history, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flying through the clouds.  A royal feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the Democrats have increased their majority in the House and the Senate.  As the new term begins, there is mounting evidence of strong hostility to President Nixon's mandate for a "New American Revolution."  However, it does not seem that the Watergate investigations have, up to now, damaged Nixon politically in any significant way ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON looks out the window, turns to HALDEMAN next to him making notes on his ubiquitous clipboard.  ZIEGLER is nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, they all miss the point.  Probably our biggest achievement as an administration, when it's all said and done, isn't China or Russia.  It's pulling out of Vietnam without a right wing revolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you're right, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but even the presidency isn't enough anymore ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The presidency won't protect us, Bob.  We're beyond politics now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman is puzzled.  EHRLICHMAN enters the cabin, excite extending a cable.  He is followed by long-haired JOHN DEAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, just in from Paris -- the Vietnamese have accepted!  Henry's peace proposal.  The bombing worked!  They're caving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon reads Kissinger's cable, but he doesn't express any happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Congratulations, boss. (handshake offered) A great victory!  The madman theory wasn't so crazy after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) This could be it ... this could be it.  Four long years ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's on his way back to meet us.  He wants to make sure he gets in all the photographs.  Incidentally ... maybe this isn't the right time but ... uh, you should know ... Bill Sullivan over at the FBI got back to us with his report on Kissinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks up, interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah ... Sullivan thinks Henry's leaking.  He's the one ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I knew it.  I knew it from '69 on, and I said it all along, didn't I ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon's expression changes totally, narrowing, cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you didn't, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he talked to Joe Kraft ... and to the Times.  Told them he was dead set against the bombing, that you were ... "unstable."  Claims he has to handle you "with kid gloves" ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting on Nixon, who goes into some inner state alone, dark brows furrowing with built-up rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his darker side emerging) So that explains his press notices.  Working both sides of the fence: Jewboy Henry, always trying to get his Nobel Prize, get laid ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in his own world) My God, my God!  He talked to the New York Times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to fire his whining ass.  Right now when he's on top.  You know what -- it'll set the right example for the rest of this administration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would personally enjoy doing that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conflicted) No, no.  He's our only "star" right now.  He'd go crying straight to the press.  He'd crucify us -- the sonofabitch! (lethal) Get someone from our staff on his ass.  Tap his phones.  I want to know everyone he talks to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll see how long the Kissinger mystique lasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a foul mood now, paranoia setting in like a storm clou on his face, Nixon shifts back to Dean, who is scared of this Nixon and tries to pacify him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what about those Watergate clowns, John?  This fuck Sirica's crazy.  Thirty-five-year sentences!  There were no weapons.  Right?  No injuries.  There was no success!  It's just ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sirica's just trying to force one of them to testify.  But they're solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what about this Washington Post crap?  Woodwind and Fernstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (corrects him) Bernstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are they? (to Haldeman) Bob, are you working on revoking the Posts's television license? (Haldeman nods) Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're trying to connect Bob and John to a secret fund, but they don't have much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a look to Ehrlichman) They don't have anything on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI's feeding me all their reports.  I didn't think you should lose any more sleep on it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters, relieved) Good man, John, good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all fall silent, feeling that false sense of securit as the sound of the jet engines takes over.  Suddenly, there is an air pocket and they rock back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: NIXON is concluding his statement to the PRESS.  HALDEMAN in the background with ZIEGLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I can therefore announce that our long and tragic involvement in Vietnam is at an end.  Our mission is accomplished, we have a cease-fire, our prisoners of war are coming back, and South Vietnam has the right to determine its own future.  We have peace with honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The REPORTERS are immediately on their feet.  A MONTAGE o QUICK CUTS follows to give the impression of a hostile an never-ending barrage of questions without satisfactory answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, isn't it true little has been achieved in this peace agreement that the Communists have not been offering since 1969?  That in fact your administration has needlessly prolonged the war and, at certain stages, has escalated it to new levels of violence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, what is your reaction to James McCord's statement that high White House officials were involved in the Watergate break-in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the Washington Post is reporting that Mr. Haldeman and Mr. Ehrlichman have secretly disbursed up to $900,000 in campaign funds.  Is there any truth to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) I've said before and I'll say again: I will not respond to the charges of the Washington Post.  Nor will I comment on a matter that's currently before the courts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you intend to cooperate with Senator Ervin's committee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you agree to the appointment of a special prosecutor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The questions flood in.  Nixon is overwhelmed.  He gather his papers and starts to move off.  A darkly funny thing happens: ZIEGLER wanders into his path, almost colliding. Nixon, pissed, grabs Ziegler by the shoulders, spins him back towards the REPORTERS, and pushes him at them.  Ziegler stumbles, looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON storms into his office, picking up an ashtray and hurling it across the room -- it shatters against the wal Everyone in the room with him -- KISSINGER, HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN -- is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I end the longest war in American history and they keep harping on this chickenshit!  You know who's behind this, don't you -- it's Teddy Kennedy!  He drowns a broad in his car and he can't run for president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got pretty burned at Chappaquiddick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My point exactly!  Somebody had to die before his shit got in the paper!  Fucking Kennedys get away with everything.  Do you see me screwing everything that moves? (then) For Christ's sake!  I did what the New York Times editorial page said we should do!  I ended the war, I got SALT I with the Russians, I opened China!  So why are these cocksuckers turning on me?  Because they don't like the way I look.  Where I went to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they're not Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  They don't trust!  They don't trust America!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (venting with him) Why would they?!  Who the hell's Sulzberger anyway?  Their parents are gold traders from Eastern Europe.  They buy things.  They come to Jew York City and they buy up things.  One of the things they buy is the New York Times. (glares at Kissinger) And you know what?  Be proud because they'll never trust you, sir, because we speak for the average American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ehrlichman shares a look with Kissinger as Nixon and Haldeman feed into each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why they're turning on me?  They're not serious about power, that's why.  They're playing with power.  They're forgetting the national interest.  In the old days, people knew how to hold power, how to set limits.  They wouldn't have torn this country apart over a third-rate burglary.  All they care about now are their egos, looking good at cocktail parties ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... beating out the other papers, chasing girls ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... worrying whether someone said something "nice" about them.  All short-term, frivolous bullshit; Ben Bradlee worrying about Teddy Kennedy liking him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger tries to get the focus back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I feel we're drifting toward oblivion here.  We're playing a totally reactive game; we've got to get ahead of the ball. (pause, in an embarrassed voice) We all know you're clean ... Right?  So let's do a housecleaning.  Take the gloves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman shares a look with Ehrlichman.  Is he referring them?  Nixon turns slowly on Kissinger, cryptic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Housecleaning?  It would be ugly, Henry, really ugly ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it must be done; your government is paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds of shit would come out.  Like the Ellsberg thing.  You knew about that, Henry, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vague) I ... I heard something ... It sounded idiotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idiotic?  Yes, I suppose it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're the one who said we should expose him as some kind of sex fiend.  Someone took you literally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung, and suddenly knowledgeable) I never suggested for some imbeciles to go break into a psychiatrist's office.  How stupid of ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't matter now, Henry.  The point is, you might lose some of your media-darling halo if the press starts sniffing around our dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant) I had nothing to do with that, sir, and I resent any implication ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resent it all you want, Henry, but you're in it with the rest of us.  Cambodia, Ellsberg, the wiretaps you put in.  The President wants you to know you can't just click your heels and head back to Harvard Yard.  It's your ass too, Henry, and it's in the wind twisting with everyone else's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stony silence.  The men, all clenched jaws, wait.  Kissinger, icily, clicks his heels and withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) Mr. Nixon, it is possible for even a president to go too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon laughs maniacally.  JOHN DEAN crosses in as Kissing exits.  Dean closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You played it perfectly, sir -- cocksucker!  He's going to think twice before he leaks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exultant) He'll be looking in his toilet bowl every time he pulls the chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh madly, like hatters at a tea party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Mr. President, Hunt wants more money.  Another hundred-and-thirty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says if he doesn't get it right away, he's going to blow us out of the water.  And he means it.  Ever since his wife died in the plane crash, he's been over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay him.  Pay him what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to turn the faucet off on this thing.  It's out of control ... (as he crosses to Dean, sotto voce) You might burden just me with this in the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Helms -- it's got to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could leverage Helms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I met with him, he said ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELMS, sitting across from HALDEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this entire affair, the President wants you to know, is related to the Bay of Pigs, and if it opens up ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helms grips the arms of his chair, leans forward excitedl and yells at Haldeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bay of Pigs had nothing to do with this!  I have no concern about the Bay of Pigs!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman is shocked by Helms's violent reaction, but remains very cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what the President told me to relay to you, Mr. Helms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (settling back) All right ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME SCENE - HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN, DEAN and NIXON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fishing) ... I was wondering what's such dynamite in this Bay of Pigs story? (Nixon stares, nothing) ... although it was clearly effective,  because all of a sudden it was no problem for Helms to go to the FBI and try to put a lid on Watergate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the documents he promised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll give us the documents. (then) But I think he should be offered the ambassadorship to Iran.  Then he'll go without a whimper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stares at him, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised Iran to Townsend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put Townsend in Belgium; it's available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Townsend gave us 300 grand.  Belgium's not worth more than 100, 150 ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about England?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  Ehrenberg's paid three times that much ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helms wants Iran or there might be problems.  All of his old CIA buddies are over there making a fortune off the Shah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, when does this end?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Executive clemency ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt has nothing to lose now.  Pardon all of them.  Nobody's going to investigate a crime for which the criminals have already been pardoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that.  That's a solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll never wash.  Pardoning them means we're guilty.  The people, the press will go nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what am I supposed to do?  Just sit here and watch them coming closer?  Eating their way to the center? (paces) Lyndon bugged!  So did Kennedy!  FDR cut a deal with Lucky Luciano.  Christ, even Ike had a mistress!  What's so special about me? (then) What about Lyndon?  He could make a couple of calls to the Hill and shut this whole thing down.  Did anyone talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) I did.  He hit the roof.  No dice.  He says if you come out with a story about how he bugged your plane, he's going to reveal ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Ehrlichman and Dean, pauses. We CUT ACROSS the room from Ehrlichman's point of view as Haldeman whispers the rest of the message in Nixon's ear. Nixon's face goes ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low key) All right ... all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) I don't know, I don't know ... I just know we've made too many enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Bob and I are gonna have to testify before Earvin's committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not!  You're going to claim executive privilege and you're going to stonewall it all the way -- plead the Fifth Amendment.  I don't give a shit.  They can't force the President's people to testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Executive privilege will make it look like we're covering up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are covering up!  For some petty, stupid shit. (then) There are things I can say -- when other people say them, they'd be lies.  But when I say them nobody believes me anyway ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  A look between Haldeman and Ehrlichman, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're going to have to give them Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon turns, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell?  Mitchell's ... family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either it goes to Mitchell or it comes here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks like he's just been punched in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) John's right.  It's not personal, boss.  It's just the way the game is played.  Sometimes you have to punt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks out the window.  Suddenly, he looks very old and very tired in the gray Washington light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'm so goddamn worn out with this ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALDEMAN and EHRLICHMAN leave the President's office.  They're pensive, on the move.  They come to a huddle next to a window in an isolated alcove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's gonna tell Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause he hates you.  It's worse when you get it from someone you trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wrong, you know -- about Kennedy, LBJ, Truman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, they did stuff, but nothing like this, Bob.  Forget Watergate, the break-ins, the Enemies list.  You got an attempted firebombing at the Brookings Institution, planting McGovern stuff on the guy that shot Wallace, trying to slip LSD to Jack Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Old Man" plays politics harder than anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is just about politics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go inanimate as a White House STAFFER passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately) You think LBJ would ever have asked Hunt to forge a cable implicating John Kennedy in the assassination of the President of Vietnam? (whispering fiercely) How long have you known him, Bob?  Twenty years? (then) You ever shake hands with him?  You ever have a real conversation with him?  We don't have a clue what's going on inside that man.  And look what we're doing for him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ehrlichman glances around to make sure no one is listenin He leans close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about Richard Nixon.  You got people dying because he didn't make the varsity football team.  You got the Constitution hanging by a thread because the "Old Man" went to Whittier and not to Yale. (then) And what the hell is this "Bay of Pigs" thing?  He goes white every time it gets mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman, more bothered than he pretends, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a code or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low whisper) I think he means the Kennedy assassination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went after Castro.  In some crazy way it got turned on Kennedy.  I don't think the "P" knows what happened, but he's afraid to find out.  It's got him shitting peach pits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, we created Frankenstein with those fucking Cubans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman sighs, lets his guard down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight words back in '72 -- "I covered up.  I was wrong.  I'm sorry" -- and the American public would've forgiven him.  But we never opened our mouths, John.  We failed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Nixon saying "I'm sorry"?  That'll be the day.  The whole suit of armor'd fall off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you tell Mitchell ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN DEAN stands at the center of the bridge, looks down the Potomac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyndon Johnson passed away today at 74 -- one of the most tragic of American presidents ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're early, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean jumps.  Turns.  HOWARD HUNT is standing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sorry to hear about your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look) Yes ... I got the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President would like to know if that was the last payment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) In Richard Nixon's long history of underhanded dealings, he has never gotten better value for his money.  If I were to open my mouth, all the dominoes would fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you have the temerity to blackmail the President of the United States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the question, John.  The question is: Why is he paying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To protect his people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one of his people.  The Cubans are his people.  And we're going to jail for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard, you'll serve no more than two years, then he'll pardon you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights his pipe) John, sooner or later -- sooner, I think -- you are going to learn the lesson that has been learned by everyone who has ever gotten close to Richard Nixon.  That he's the darkness reaching out for the darkness.  And eventually, it's either you or him.  Look at the landscape of his life and you'll see a boneyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunt throws a match into the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And he's already digging your grave, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN DEAN, looking glum, walks down the corridors for his meeting with the President.  Passing the SECRETARIES who look at him -- that furtive look of people who sense crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI Director-designate, L. Patrick Gray, shocked the Senate by revealing that John Dean has been secretly receiving FBI reports on Watergate ... Gray also said that Dean lied when he claimed Howard Hunt did not have an office in the White House ...

dialogues.speaker: SUBTITLE READS
dialogues.text: DEAN is explaining his new outlook to a quiet NIXON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... this is just the sort of thing Mafia people can do -- washing money, and things like that.  We just don't know about these things because we're not criminals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Nixon listening behind his desk, hands cupped over his mouth, frown across his face -- the classic Nixon image o a deep thinker.  The CAMERA drops across his desk.  And moves towards a MIKE drilled in the edge of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of TAPE RECORDERS labelled "Oval Office," "Lincoln Room," "Phones 1-6," "EOB," is rolling.  BACK TO SCENE AT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I would say these people are going to cost a million dollars over the next two years ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could get a million dollars.  We could get it in cash.  I know where it could be gotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT: the TAPE rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I'm still not confident we can ride through this.  Some people are going to have to go to jail.  Hunt's not the only problem.  Haldeman let me use the $350,000 cash fund in his safe to make the payments.  Ehrlichman had a role, a big role, in the Ellsberg break-in.  And I'm ... uh, I think it's time we begin to think in terms of cutting our losses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried about Dean) You say, John, cut our losses and all the rest.  But suppose the thing blows and they indict Bob and the others.  Jesus, you'd never recover from that, John.  It's better to fight it out instead, and not let people testify ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I still don't think, uh, we can contain it anymore.  There's a cancer on the presidency.  And it's growing.  With every day that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, everything is a crisis among the upper intellectual types, the softheads.  The average people don't think it's much of a crisis.  For Christ's sake, it's not Vietnam ... no one's dying here.  Isn't it ridiculous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree it's ridiculous but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, who the hell cares about this penny-ante shit.  Goldwater put it right.  He said: "Well for Christ's sake, everybody bugs everybody else; we know that." ... It's the cover-up, not the deed that's really bad here. (then) If only Mitchell could step up and take the brunt of it; give them the hors d'oeuvre and maybe they won't come back for the main course.  That's the tragedy of all this.  Mitchell's going to get it in the neck anyway.  It's time he assumed some responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean has a nervous look in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't.  He told Ehrlichman he won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lightning-like IMAGE reveals MITCHELL, responding to EHRLICHMAN.  This is Nixon's mind at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell Brother Dick I got suckered into this thing by not paying attention to what these bastards were doing.  I don't have a guilty conscience ... And he shouldn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon glances towards the microphone as he moves around t desk to get closer to Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and clear) He's right.  Maybe it's time to go to the hang-out route, John.  A full and thorough investigation ... We've cooperated with the FBI, we'll cooperate with the Senate.  What do we have to hide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompted) No, we have nothing to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) We have nothing to hide. (then) But the only flaw in the plan is that they're not going to believe the truth.  That is the incredible thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean, who is worried about his own hide if the truth come out, sees the point of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.  It's tricky.  Everything seems to lead back here, and, uh ... people would never understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon awkwardly puts his arm around Dean's shoulder.  Dea begins to sense a betrayal in the offing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
