dialogues.text: John, I want you to get away from this madhouse, these reporters, and go up to Camp David for the weekend.  And I want you to write up a report.  I want you to put everything you know about Watergate in there.  Say: Mr. President, here it all is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another lightning-like IMAGE is Nixon's worst fear -- JOH DEAN is at the table, plea-bargaining with TWO PROSECUTOR their backs to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to put it all in writing?  Over my signature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows more about this thing than you do, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to be the scapegoat for this.  Haldeman and Ehrlichman are in just as deep as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, you don't want to start down that road.  I remember what Whittaker Chambers told me back in '48 -- and he was a man who suffered greatly -- he said, "On the road of the informer, it's always night." (then) This is beyond you or even me.  It's the country, John.  It's the presidency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  You know how I feel about loyalty.  I'm not going to let any of my people go to jail.  That I promise you. (moves closer) The important thing is to keep this away from Haldeman and Ehrlichman.  I'm trusting you to do that, John.  I have complete confidence in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Dean's face we:

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION SCREEN
dialogues.text: NIXON on the TV screen, shaken, ashen-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was determined that we should get to the bottom of Watergate, and the truth should be fully brought out no matter who was involved ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD HELMS, absently watching NIXON on TV, carries a handful of documents to a CIA incinerator.  He drops them in the fire, watches them burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggles) Today, in one of the most difficult decisions of my presidency, I accepted the resignations of two of my closest associates -- Bob Haldeman and John Ehrlichman -- two of the finest public servants it has been my privilege to know ... The counsel to the President, John Dean, has also resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Helms burning documents. LIMBO - HALDEMAN watches TV, his WIFE and CHILDREN next t him.  He thinks back to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman's mind -- the last one-to-one session.  HALDEMAN leaves the office, looking back over his shoulder at NIXO alone in the gathering shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More light, chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted, waves) No ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haldeman exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There can be no whitewash at the White House ... two wrongs do not make a right.  I love America.  God bless America and God bless each and every one of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Sir ... six bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife puts her hand on his knee in support.  He squeez her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LIMBO
dialogues.text: EHRLICHMAN also watches, with FAMILY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits at his desk, holding a rigid expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ... we're clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay on Nixon as the film lights go off, leaving him i shadow.  He is devastated. ALEXANDER HAIG, Nixon's new chief-of-staff, seen earlier, watches Nixon for a moment, turns to a VIDEO CREW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON at one end of the lengthy table, PAT at the other, eat in a dreadful silence, attended by MANOLO and SERVANT who move nervously, anxious to have the dinner over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at last) I'm giving a tea for the wives of the POWs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to Key Biscayne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron told me that Bob Haldeman's been calling.  But you won't talk to him ... if he's convicted, will you pardon him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Why are you cutting yourself off from the rest of us? (then) Can't we discuss this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon slowly sets his spoon down.  An icy stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly did you want to discuss, Pat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.  What' you're doing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) And what am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew.  You're hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is you've always been hiding.  You're letting it destroy you, Dick.  You won't even ask for help.  You're destroying yourself, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon pauses, rings the dinner bell.  MANOLO reappears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nixon is finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat looks as if she's been slapped; slowly puts down her silverware.  MANOLO clears away her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only left, Dick.  If you don't talk to me, you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brezhnev's coming in three days.  I don't want to deal with them.  And him.  And you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat sits rigid for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much more?  How much more is it going to cost?  When do the rest of us stop paying off your debts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon puts down his fork, embarrassed.  Manolo has beaten hasty retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to finish my dinner in peace.  It's not too much to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat stands slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't.  I won't interfere with you anymore.  I'm finished trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Thank you? (then) Dick, sometimes I understand why they hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon watches her walk out the door.  Then, he picks up h fork and continues eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawls) The Senate Select Committee on Watergate will come to order ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gavel POUNDS O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON STAFFERS are gathered around Haig's TV set at as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN DEAN reads his statement to the COMMITTEE.  Conservatively groomed, horn-rimmed glasses, shorter hair Dean speaks in a monotone.  A pretty blond woman, his WIF sits noticeably behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it was a tremendous disappointment to me because it was quite clear that the cover-up, as far as the White House was concerned, was going to continue ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying sack of shit!  Little mommy's boy -- go tell the teacher, will ya ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIG looks at Dean on TV, shakes his head, disgusted, and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weasel's got no proof.  Just remember that it's still an informer's word against the President's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIG walks past STAFF into the Oval Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (droning on) ... it was apparent to me I had failed in turning the President around ... I reached the conclusion that Ehrlichman would never admit to his involvement in the cover-up ... I assumed that Haldeman would not, because he would believe it was a higher duty to protect the President ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIG slides into the room where NIXON and LEONID BREZHNEV Premier of the USSR, are engaged in a friendly meeting through an INTERPRETER.  ANDREI GROMYKO completes the glu Soviet threesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian) ... Mao told me in 1963: "If I have nuclear weapons, let 400 million Chinese die, 300 million will be left." (leans closer) Mao suffers from a mental disorder; we know this a long time in my country. (then) This is the man you want to be your ally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was your ally for twenty years, Leonid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes a funny gesture) Yes, yes, Dick.  Life is always the best teacher, you know this -- and you too will discover how treacherous he can be.  But it must not interfere with the building of a SALT II treaty between our great countries.  Peace in our era is possible ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks to Haig, who whispers something in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon and Haig move to a corner of the room, whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gromyko) If Haldeman and Ehrlichman are indicted, it will wound him, perhaps fatally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on who they believe -- Nixon or Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brezhnev looks at Nixon, who is visibly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Incredible.  He looks like a man with little time left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon's daughter, JULIE, earnest, bright-eyed, looks at h father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Did you ... Daddy?  Did you cover it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON looks at her steadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I would do something like that, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie shakes her head vigorously, then puts her hands to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can't resign!  You just can't.  You're one of the best presidents this country's ever had!  You've done what Lincoln did.  You've brought this country back from civil war!  You can't let your enemies tear you down! (calmer) You've got to stay and fight.  I'll go out there and make speeches, Dad.  No one knows the real you.  How sweet you are, how nice you are to people.  I'll tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She embraces him almost desperately, kissing him on the forehead, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, you are the most decent person I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) I hope I haven't let you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging him through her tears) They just don't know; they don't know the real you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Nixon - CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT is still wearing her nightdress, coffee and cigarette in hand, as her press secretary, HELEN SMITH, runs throug a sheaf of papers.  A TELEVISION drones in the background

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheery) ... and on Friday we have the high school students from Ohio, Saturday is the Women's National Republican Club ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a development that could break Watergate wide open, Alexander Butterfield, testifying today before the Senate Select Committee, revealed the existence of a taping system that may have recorded conversations in the White House, the EOB, and the Camp David retreat ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat glances up over the top of her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on Sunday you're saying hello to the VFW Poppy Girl ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She realizes Pat is not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Nixon ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close: on Pat as she slowly raises a hand to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White House sources say that over the past three years, President Nixon has recorded virtually every conversation he has had, including those with his staff, and even members of his own family ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits in his bed, alone, still in his pajamas.  It's clear he hasn't slept.  He looks shell-shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a stunning revelation.  If such tapes exist, they could tell us once and for all: What did the President know and when did he know it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA closing on NIXON.  His deepest secrets are now being revealed.  He begins coughing violently.  He tries cover his mouth, but notices now that his hand and the sheets around him are covered with blood.  He screams, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God - Pat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON on a gurney, being wheeled down a hospital corridor PAT, wearing dark sunglasses, is with him, very concerned A plastic mask is over his face. He struggles to get up, but a NURSE gently presses him ba down.  SECRET SERVICE AGENTS surround the gurney.  HAIG clears the corridors nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear the path!  The President is coming through.  Clear a path.  I'm in charge here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT gets the DOCTOR's attention on the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately) Is it TB?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He's sure he has tuberculosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's an acute viral pneumonia. (lowers his voice) But that's not what we're worried about.  We found an inflammation in his left leg.  It's phlebitis ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Nixon, eyes closed; the overhead lights reflect the mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watergate Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox has broadened his investigation to include President's Nixon's business dealings and house payments.  Nixon apparently paid no income tax in the years 1970, '71 and '72 ... and may have illegally used government funds to improve his San Clemente Western White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIG holds open the doors as the ORDERLIES push Nixon int the respiratory unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR and NURSE remove the mask from NIXON'S face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attorney General Elliot Richardson will present evidence to a grand jury that Vice President Agnew is guilty of bribery, extortion and tax evasion ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon immediately starts gasping.  He again tries to rise but hands push him back.  The doctor fits the mouthpiece the respirator into Nixon's mouth.  Images of the Beast pervade the room. Nixon begins breathing ... His eyes going past PAT to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA MITCHELL is acting strangely behind enormous sunglasses -- at an impromptu interview on the STREET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Can you keep a secret, honey?  Tween you, me and the gatepost, Tricky Dick always knew what was going on ... every last goddamn detail.  And my husband's not taking the rap this time ... They know they can't shut me up, so they'll probably end up killing me, but I depend on you, the press, to protect me ... and my husband, because that's what it's going to come to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN MITCHELL, angry, beleaguered, bypasses cameras outsi a COURTHOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know what she's talking about.  Stop bothering her.  She's not well.  Hell, she's nuts -- you bastards've seen to that. (brushing past another question) You can stick it right up your keester, fella.  Our marriage is finished, thank you very much ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON in the hospital, breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archibald Cox declared war on President Nixon today by issuing a subpoena for nine of the President's tapes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells) Never!  Over my dead body!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON, his leg swollen, limps down the corridor, furious. HAIG walks with him, ZIEGLER and the lawyer, BUZHARDT, bringing up the rear.  HAIG clears the corridor of potential eavesdroppers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the President's personal property!  I will never give up my tapes to a bunch of Kennedy-loving Harvard Democrat cocksuckers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could trigger the impeachment.  They'll go to the Supreme Court next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let 'em try!  I appointed three of those bastards!  I'm not giving 'em my tapes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the president afford to ignore a subpoena?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck does Cox think he is? (fumes) I never made a dime from public office!  I'm honest.  My dad died broke.  You know the sonofabitch went to law school with Jack Kennedy? ... The last gasp of the Establishment!  They got the hell kicked out of 'em in the election, so now they gotta squeal about Watergate 'cause we were the first real threat to them in years.  And by God, Al, we would have changed it, changed it so they couldn't have changed it back in a hundred years, if only ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congress is considering four articles of impeachment, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the charges are serious -- first, abuse of power; second, obstruction of justice; third, failure to cooperate with Congress; and last, bombing Cambodia ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't impeach me for bombing Cambodia.  The President can bomb anybody he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we'll win that one, but the other three ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Fred, they sell tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sell tickets to an impeachment.  Like a fucking circus ... Okay, so they impeach me.  Then it's a question of mathematics.  How many votes do we have in the Senate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a dozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wounded) A dozen?  I got half of 'em elected.  I still got the South and Goldwater and his boys.  I'll take my chances with the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll have to deal with the possibility of removal from office, loss of pension, possibly ... prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, plenty of people did their best writing in prison.  Gandhi, Lenin ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, glowers darkly) What I know about this country, I ... I could rip it apart.  If they want a public humiliation, that's what they'll get.  But I will never resign this office.  Where the fuck am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him strangely.  They've stopped at the doors of the East Room.  The SOUND of VOICES and VIOLIN playing inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ziegler) What's in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POWs.  And their families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm supposed to be ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compassionate.  Grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Haig, bitterly) Fire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cox!  Fire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he works for the Attorney General.  Only Richardson can fire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) Sir, if I may ... echo my concern ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Buzhardt, to Haig) Then tell Richardson to fire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richardson won't do that.  He'll resign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell he will!  Fire him, too.  If you have to go all the way down to the janitor at the Justice Department, fire the sonofabitch!  And ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I just say something, sir?  I think you should welcome the subpoena.  The tapes can only prove that Dean is a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more ... there's more than just me.  You can't break, my boy, even when there's nothing left.  You can't admit, even to yourself, that it's gone, Al.  (pointing to the East Room) Do you think those POWs in there did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now some people, we both know them, Al, think you can go stand in the middle of the bullring and cry, "Mea culpa, mea culpa," while the crowd is hissing and booing and spitting on you.  But a man doesn't cry. (then) I don't cry.  You don't cry ... You fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT soft IMAGES over NIXON being pounded at FOOTBALL Nixon straightens himself, puts on a smile, nods to Ziegler.  Ziegler opens the door.  A ROAR of CHEERS and MARTIAL MUSIC greets the President, as he disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We interrupt this program for a special report from NBC News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER appears, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country tonight is in the midst of what may be the most serious constitutional crisis in history.  In the wake of Vice President Spiro Agnew's forced resignation on charges of corruption, President Nixon has fired Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY IMAGES - ARCHIBALD COX walking in the street, having heard the news, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attorney General Elliot Richards has resigned rather than comply with the President's order, and Deputy Attorney General William Ruckelshaus was fired when he refused to carry out the order ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCUMENTARY IMAGES - FBI AGENTS carrying boxes of files o of the Special Prosecutor's office.  RUCKELSHAUS getting into a car, refusing to comment.  ELLIOT RICHARDSON movin down the gauntlet of REPORTERS.  We CUT BACK to the REPORTER on camera, grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, the country, without a Vice President, stands poised at a crossroads -- has a government of laws become a government of one man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, the black iron bars.  The facade of the mansio The light in the second floor.  We move in slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is really drunk now, listening to some GIBBERISH on the tape.  We move in on his profile, framed by Lincoln i the background.  We should not be able to make out the voices -- occasional words like "Castro," "Kennedy."  But that's about it ... nothing more.  And as we move closer Nixon, bleary-eyed, we should feel he has no idea, either of what he's listening to.  It's just ... noise.  PAT's voice cuts in.  She's standing at the doorway.  She's bee drinking too, but is sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're like love letters.  You should burn them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon, startled, tries to shut off the tape, but he hits the wrong button and we hear high-speed VOICES in reverse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurs) You can't expect me to explain that to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What matters to me is whether you understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  He finally gets the tape stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're evidence.  You can't legally destroy evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't expect me to believe that for one minute, do you? (then) Does it matter what's on them?  Really? ... Murder, Dick?  Sex?  Your secrets, your fantasies?  Or just me and you and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember Alger Hiss.  I know how ugly you can be -- you're capable of anything.  But you see, it doesn't really matter, at the end of the day, what's on them.  Because you have absolutely no remorse.  No concept of remorse.  You want the tapes to get out, you want them to see you at your worst ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're drunk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat laughs, "Yeah, I am."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one will ever see those tapes.  Including you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what would I find out that I haven't known for years. (then) What makes it so damn sad is that you couldn't confide in any of us.  You had to make a record ... for the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were for me.  They're mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  They're not yours.  They are you.  You should burn them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks out.  Nixon is turbulent, upset.  He turns and suddenly sees the ghost of his young mother, HANNAH, sitting there in the shadows, staring at him. He jumps.  Those eyes of hers.  Penetrating, gazing right through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has changed in thee, Richard ... When thou were a boy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurts out) No!  Please!  Don't talk to me!  Anything ... but don't talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHARP CUT snaps us from the reverie, and Nixon is alone in his sitting room, the door closed, the VOICE on the ta droning.  He downs pills with the Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... these guys went after Castro.  Seven times, ten times ... What do you think -- people like that, they just give up?  They just walk away? (then) Whoever killed Kennedy came from this ... this thing we created.  This Beast ... That's why we can't let this thing go any farther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over at the recorder, slowly turning.  He pushes "Stop" and then runs it back on "Rewind."  High-speed voices.  He pushes "Stop" again.  A series of TIME CUTS shows Nixon getting drunker, playing all sections of the tape.  The camera closes on the tape machine.  It's all a blur as we hear a HUM growing louder and louder, as we in in on an abstract CLOSE-UP of the TAPE moving across the capstan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the latest bombshell, the President's lawyers revealed that there is an eighteen-and-a-half minute gap in a critical Watergate tape ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frenzy of paperwork as the PRESIDENT'S LAWYERS -- BUZHARDT and ST. CLAIR -- sit hunched around a table pile with transcripts, helped by TWO YOUNG ASSISTANTS. NIXON is aghast as he reads some of the highlighted sections.  HAIG and ZIEGLER attend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In an attempt to head off impeachment proceedings, the President has agreed to release transcripts of forty-six taped conversations ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In a simple ceremony, Gerald Ford was sworn in as Vice President.  A longtime, popular member of Congress, Ford reinforces a sense of ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... citing White House wrong-doing, the judge has dismissed all charges against Daniel Ellsberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the grand jury has indicted former Nixon aides Bob Haldeman, John Ehrlichman and former Attorney General John Mitchell ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon shakes the paper in the faces of Buzhardt and St. Clair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lawyers.  How can you let this shit go by! (points) Look!  This?  Nixon can't say this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did say it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.  I never said that about Jews!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzhardt glances at St. Clair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could check the tape again, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to check the tape.  I know what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the Magic Marker out of the lawyer's hand and furiously blacks out an entire section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this?!  Good Lord, have you lost your mind?  Nixon can't say this.  "Niggers"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we could delete it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing the best we can, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not good enough ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can black it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or we could write "expletive deleted."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and get rid of all these "goddamns" and "Jesus Christs"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, all these deletion marks in the transcripts will make it look you swear all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon grows cold, stares steadily at St. Clair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake, it soils my mother's memory.  Do you think I want the whole goddamn world to see my mother like this?  Raising a dirty mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir, we'll have to start over from the beginning.  We don't have the staff to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon loses it, sweeps the pile of transcripts off the table.  They fly around the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) Then start over!  The world will see only what I show them.  From page one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits at his desk, grimacing tightly into the TV CAMERA.  Next to him is a stack of blue binders emblazone with the presidential seal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, my fellow Americans.  Tonight I'm taking an action unprecedented in the history of this office ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KISSINGER and HAIG watch NIXON on television.  They share drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... an action that will at last, once and for all, show that what I knew and what I did with regard to the Watergate break-in and cover-up were just as I have described them to you from the very beginning ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's completely lost touch with reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no knowledge of the cover-up until John Dean told me about it on March twenty-first.  And I did not intend that payment to Hunt or anyone else be made ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine what this man would have been had he ever been loved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... because people have got to know whether or not their President is a crook.  Well, I am not a crook.  I have never made a dime from public service ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I'm going to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll crucify him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger turns to Haig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anybody care anymore? (then) What happens after ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT sits alone, drinking, as the television drones on wit the latest invasion of her privacy.  As we move in, we se the spirit drawn out of her.  She seems numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Supreme Court ruled today eight-to zero that President Nixon's claims of "executive privilege" cannot be used in criminal cases, and that he must turn over all subpoenaed tapes ... a firestorm on Capitol Hill as ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE READS: "JULY 1974," over EMPTY SHOTS of an EMPTY HOUSE, filled with gloom and dread.  The FOOTSTEPS of two silhouettes crack the silence as they make their way towards the Lincoln Sitting Room.  It is an eerie echo of the film's opening shots of the White House.  The silhouettes now become apparent as GENERAL HAIG and HENRY KISSINGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The House Judiciary Committee has voted twenty-seven-to-eleven to recommend impeachment to the full House.  The deliberations now go to the House floor ... In its report, the Committee offers evidence that Nixon obstructed justice on at least thirty six occasions, that he encouraged his aides to commit perjury, and that he abused the powers of his office ... In a separate report, the Senate Select Committee details the misuses of the IRS, the FBI, the CIA and the Justice Department.  It denounces the Plumbers, and it raises questions of whether the United States had a valid election in 1972.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE - Haig knocks and enters the Lincoln Sitting Room.  A shaft of LIGHT from inside zigzags the darkness. And we hear a snatch of LOUD MUSIC before the door is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON sits in his chair in a suit and tie, listening to "Victory at Sea" at top volume.  In front of him is a picture album -- 1922 portraits of the NIXON FAMILY.  HAROLD holding ARTHUR.  RICHARD stares glumly at the came between HANNAH and FRANK. GENERAL HAIG, with KISSINGER behind, approaches with some papers held out in his hand.  Nixon sees them, turns down the hi-fi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Victory at Sea," Al ... Henry.  The Pacific Theatre.  Christ, you can almost feel the waves breaking over the decks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we have another problem, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands him a paper.  Nixon glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June twenty-third, '72, sir.  The part that's underlined.  Your instructions to Haldeman regarding the CIA and the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lawyers feel it's the ... "smoking gun."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's totally out of context.  I was protecting the national security.  I never intended --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the deadline is today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get around this, Al?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Supreme Court, sir; you don't get around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon, silenced, looks down at the paper in his hands and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you resign, you can keep your tapes as a private citizen ... You can fight them for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks up at him, then over at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln used it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was civil war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you see this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon closes his eyes.  Haig takes the transcript back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't survive this, sir.  They also have you instructing Dean to make the payoff to Hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing in that statement the President can't explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you talked about opening up the whole "Bay of Pigs" thing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three days before, on the June twentieth tape -- the one with the eighteen-minute gap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I don't know anything about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues) ... you mentioned the "Bay of Pigs" several times.  Sooner or later they're going to want to know what that means.  They're going to want to know what was on that gap ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone.  No one will ever find out what's on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig moves closer and leans down, very low, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might ... if there were another ... recording.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon glances up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both know it's possible. (then) I know for a fact it's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon stares up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spoken to Ford ... And there's a very strong chance he'll pardon you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig hands him a letter of resignation. INSERT: "I hereby resign the office of President of the United States."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is something you will have to do, Mr. President.  I thought you would rather do it now ... I'll wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig drifts out as Kissinger comes out of the shadows.  Nixon looks down blankly at the sheet of paper in front o him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say, sir, if you stay now it will paralyze the nation and its foreign policy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon looks up at Kissinger.  The Judas himself -- at lea one of them.  There is irony here that is apparent to Nix but not to Kissinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you always had a good sense of timing, Henry.  When to give and when to take.  How do you think Mao, Brezhnev will react? (sitting up, suddenly intense) Do you think this is how they'll remember me, Henry, after all the great things you and I did together?  As some kind of ... of ... crooks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prepared response) They will understand, sir.  To be undone by a third-rate burglary is a fate of biblical proportions.  History will treat you far more kindly than your contemporaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends who writes the history books.  I'm not a quitter ... but I'm not stupid either ... A trial would kill me -- that's what they want. (with some satisfaction) But they won't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signs the resignation paper.  A pause.  It lies there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grandiosely) If they harass you, I, too, will resign.  And I will tell the world why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be stupid.  The world needs you, Henry; you always saw the big picture.  You were my equal in many ways. (then) You're the only friend I've got, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have many friends ... and admirers ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever pray?  You know ... believe in a Supreme Being?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... not really.  You mean on my knees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  My mother used to pray ... a lot.  It's been a long time since I really prayed. (a little lost) Let's pray, Henry; let's pray a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nixon gets down on his knees, Kissinger perspires freely.  He clumsily follows the President down to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Uh, I hope this doesn't embarrass you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  This is not going to leak, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Henry) Don't be too proud; never be too proud to go on your knees before God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prays silently, then suddenly he sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God!  Dear God, how can a country come apart like this!  What have I done wrong ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger is experiencing pure dread, his shirt soaked wi sweat.  He opens his eyes and peeks at Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I opened China.  I made peace with Russia.  I ended the war.  I tried to do what's right!  Why ... why do they hate me so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.  Nixon wraps his arms across his chest and roc back and forth in an upright fetal position.  Kissinger, looking very distressed, reaches over and touches the President, trying awkwardly to console him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (woozily at his hands) It's unbelievable, it's insane ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On that note, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A solitary SENTINEL -- a Marine Guard -- stands at strict attention, eyes forward, as we hear the VOICES of: The THREE SILHOUETTES of NIXON, KISSINGER and HAIG walkin out.  HIGH ANGLES allow us to hear their VOICES echoing o the empty rooms, and sometimes catch a glimpse of a passi face.  From the voice we can tell that Nixon has resumed his customary bluffness, a sense of bravado in the face of defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... they smelled the blood on me this time, Al.  I got soft.  You know ... that rusty, metallic smell ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it well, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came over from Vietnam, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That smell.  I mean, everybody suffered so much, their sons killed.  They need to sacrifice something, y'know, appease the gods of war -- Mars, Jupiter.  I am that blood, General.  I am that sacrifice, in the highest place of all ... All leaders must finally be sacrificed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn a corner, come into more light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things won't be the same after this.  I played by the rules, but the rules changed right in the middle of the game ... There's no respect for American institutions anymore.  People are cynical, the press -- God, the press -- is out of control, people spit on soldiers, government secrets mean nothing ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon separates from Haig and Kissinger who bid him a las "Mr. President."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remote) I pity the next guy who sits here ... Goodnight, gentlemen ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haig and Kissinger depart. Nixon shuffles back alone, coming to a stop in front of a larger-than-life, full-length oil portrait of JOHN F. KENNEDY.  Nixon studies the portrait, pads closer.  Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they look at you, they see what they want to be. (then) When they look at me, they see what they are ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT, overhearing, comes from the shadows in a nightgown.  She looks weary, crazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, please don't ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half turns to her.  He is unshaven, eyes red-rimmed, a wounded animal who can no longer defend himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't ... I just don't have the strength anymore ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice trails off.  For a moment, it looks like he's going to collapse.  Pat moves toward him to support him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be over soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... it's just going to start now ... (looks into her eyes) If I could just ... If I could just ... sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be time for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's barely aware of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once ... when I was sick, as a boy ... my mother gave me this stuff ... made me swallow it ... it made me throw up.  All over her ... I wish I could do that now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat puts her arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid, Buddy ... There's darkness out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat is crying now.  She tries to soothe him, strokes his brow like a sick child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could always see where I was going.  But it's dark out there.  God, I've always been afraid of the dark ... Buddy ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon breaks down.  She slowly leads him up the grand staircase -- into the shadows of history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EPILOGUE and END CREDITS run over NIXON as he address the assembled WHITE HOUSE STAFF.  PAT and the FAMILY flan him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I remember my old man, I think they would've called him a little man, a common man.  He didn't consider himself that way.  He was a streetcar motorman first, and then he was a farmer, and then he had a lemon ranch.  It was the poorest lemon ranch in California, I assure you.  He sold it before they found oil on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IMAGES of FRANK and HANNAH NIXON now arise in Nixon's consciousness -- a past he would never really connect his own life to.  As if it were a storybook, a fabled America that never was.  The MUSIC should, in a sense, accentuate this divorce of sentiment from reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and then he was a grocer.  But he was a great man because he did his job, and every job counts up to the hilt, regardless of what happens ... Nobody will ever write a book, probably, about my mother.  Well, I guess all of you would say this about your mother: my mother was a saint.  And I think of her, two boys dying of tuberculosis and seeing each of them die, and when they died ... Yes, she will have no books written about her.  But she was a saint ... But now, however, we look to the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon is holding himself together by sheer force of will. Many members of his STAFF are weeping.  He pulls an old well-leafed book open, puts a set of eyeglasses on to rea from it, the first time he's ever worn them in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I remember something Theodore Roosevelt wrote when his first wife died.  He was still a young man, in his twenties, and this was in his diary -- "T.R." -- ... "She was beautiful in face and form and lovelier still in spirit ... When she had just become a mother, when her life seemed to be just begun, and when the years seemed so bright before her, then by a strange and terrible fate death came to her.  And when my heart's dearest died, the light went from my life forever ..."  That was "T.R." in his twenties.  He thought the light had gone from his life forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the book, nearly cracking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But of course he went on to become President, sometimes right, sometimes wrong, always in the arena, always vital ... We sometimes think, when things happen that don't go the right way, we think that when someone dear to us dies, when we lose an election, when we suffer a defeat, that all is ended ... but that's not true.  It is only a beginning, always; because the greatness comes not when things always go good for you, but the greatness comes, and you're really tested, when you take some knocks, some disappointments, when sadness comes ... Because only if you have been in the deepest valley can you ever know how magnificent it is to be on the highest mountain ... To have served in this office is to have felt a very personal sense of kinship with each and every American.  In leaving it, I do so with this prayer.  May God's grace be with you in all the days ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MARINE CORPS HELICOPTER waits at the end of a red carpe NIXON and PAT make their way towards it, followed by FAMILY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Remember: always give your best, never get discouraged, never be petty.  Always remember: Others may hate you, but those who hate you don't win unless you hate them ... and then you destroy yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They climb the steps and Nixon turns on the top step and smiles bravely.  Then he waves good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Only then will you find what we Quakers call "peace at the center."  Au revoir -- we'll see you again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises his arms in his characteristic twin-V salute.  And we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EPILOGUE runs over a DARK SCREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nixon always maintained that if he had not been driven from office, the North Vietnamese would not have overwhelmed the South in 1975.  In a sideshow, Cambodian society was destroyed and mass genocide resulted.  In his absence, Russia and the United States returned to a decade of high-budget military expansion and near-war.  Nixon, who was pardoned by President Ford, lived to write six books and travel the world as an elder statesman.  He was buried and honored by five Presidents on April 26, 1994, less than a year after Pat Nixon died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We include a DOCUMENTARY CLIP of his FUNERAL, eulogized b President CLINTON, the four other PRESIDENTS alongside hi ROBERT DOLE eulogizes him as a "great American."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the remainder of his life, Nixon fought successfully to protect his tapes.  The National Archives spent fourteen years indexing and cataloguing them.  Out of four thousand hours, only sixty hours have been made public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We end on an IMAGE OF YORBA LINDA, CALIFORNIA ... turn of the twentieth century where it began.  We focus on the faces of the early pioneers who settled the land -- we drift over the faces of HANNAH and FRANK, in their stern postures -- past the BROTHERS, including the two deceased ones ... to little RICHARD, eyes all aglow with the hopes of the new century.
